   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Brazil</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Largest country in South America
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the country in South America. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Brazil_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Brazil (disambiguation)">Brazil (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p> <span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Brazil&amp;params=10_S_52_W_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">10°S</span> <span class="longitude">52°W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">10°S 52°W</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">-10; -52</span></span></span></a></span></span></span> </p>

      <p><b>Brazil</b> (<a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>: <i lang="pt">Brasil</i>; <span style="font-size:85%;">Brazilian Portuguese:&nbsp;</span><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Portuguese" title="Help:IPA/Portuguese">[bɾaˈziw]</a></span>),<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[nt 4]</a></sup> officially the <b>Federative Republic of Brazil</b> (Portuguese: <span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pt-br-Rep%C3%BAblica_Federativa_do_Brasil.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b7/Pt-br-Rep%C3%BAblica_Federativa_do_Brasil.ogg" class="internal" title="Pt-br-República Federativa do Brasil.ogg"><i>República Federativa do Brasil</i></a></span></span>),<sup id="cite_ref-Bello1966v_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bello1966v-15">[11]</a></sup> is the largest country in both <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a> and <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>. At 8.5&nbsp;million square kilometers (3.2&nbsp;million square miles)<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[12]</a></sup> and with over 211 million people, Brazil is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">fifth-largest country by area</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">sixth most populous</a>. Its capital is <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Brasília">Brasília</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Brazil_by_population" title="List of cities in Brazil by population">its most populous city</a> is <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>. The federation is composed of the union of the 26 <a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">states</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Federal_District_(Brazil)" title="Federal District (Brazil)">Federal District</a>. It is the largest country to have <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a> as an <a href="/wiki/List_of_territorial_entities_where_Portuguese_is_an_official_language" title="List of territorial entities where Portuguese is an official language">official language</a> and the only one in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-Philander2012_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Philander2012-17">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CrocittiVallance2011_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CrocittiVallance2011-18">[14]</a></sup> it is also one of the most <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">multicultural</a> and ethnically diverse nations, due to over a century of mass <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Brazil" title="Immigration to Brazil">immigration from around the world</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[15]</a></sup> as well as the most populous <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">Roman Catholic-majority country</a>. </p>
      <p>Bounded by the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> on the east, Brazil has a <a href="/wiki/Coastline_of_Brazil" title="Coastline of Brazil">coastline</a> of 7,491 kilometers (4,655&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-20">[16]</a></sup> It borders all other countries in South America except <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> and covers 47.3% of the continent's land area.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[17]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Amazon_basin" title="Amazon basin">Amazon basin</a> includes a <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">vast tropical forest</a>, home to diverse <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">wildlife</a>, a variety of <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_Brazil" title="Environment of Brazil">ecological systems</a>, and extensive natural resources spanning numerous <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Brazil" title="Protected areas of Brazil">protected habitats</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-20">[16]</a></sup> This unique environmental heritage makes Brazil one of 17 <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a>, and is the subject of significant global interest, environmental degradation through processes like <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_Brazil" title="Deforestation in Brazil">deforestation</a> has direct impacts on global issues like <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Brazil" title="Climate change in Brazil">climate change</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_loss" title="Biodiversity loss">biodiversity loss</a>. </p>
      <p>Brazil was inhabited by <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Brazil" title="Indigenous peoples in Brazil">numerous tribal nations</a> prior to the landing in 1500 of explorer <a href="/wiki/Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral" title="Pedro Álvares Cabral">Pedro Álvares Cabral</a>, who claimed the area for the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese Empire</a>. Brazil remained a <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Brazil" title="Colonial Brazil">Portuguese colony</a> until 1808 when the capital of the empire was <a href="/wiki/Transfer_of_the_Portuguese_court_to_Brazil" title="Transfer of the Portuguese court to Brazil">transferred from Lisbon to Rio de Janeiro</a>. In 1815, the colony was elevated to the rank of kingdom upon the formation of the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Portugal,_Brazil_and_the_Algarves" title="United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a>. <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Brazil" title="Independence of Brazil">Independence</a> was achieved in 1822 with the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Brazil" title="Empire of Brazil">Empire of Brazil</a>, a unitary state governed under a constitutional monarchy and a parliamentary system. The ratification of the first constitution in 1824 led to the formation of a bicameral legislature, now called the <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress</a>. The country <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_Republic_(Brazil)" title="Proclamation of the Republic (Brazil)">became a presidential republic</a> in 1889 following a military <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">coup d'état</a>. An authoritarian <a href="/wiki/Military_dictatorship_in_Brazil" title="Military dictatorship in Brazil">military junta</a> came to power <a href="/wiki/1964_Brazilian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1964 Brazilian coup d'état">in 1964</a> and ruled until 1985, after which civilian governance resumed. Brazil's current <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">constitution</a>, formulated in 1988, defines it as a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratic</a> <a href="/wiki/Federal_republic" title="Federal republic">federal republic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> Due to its rich culture and history, the country ranks <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Brazil" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Brazil">thirteenth in the world</a> by number of <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[19]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil is classified as an upper-middle income economy by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a><sup id="cite_ref-wb-upper-middle_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wb-upper-middle-24">[20]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[21]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_wealth" title="List of countries by total wealth">the largest share of global wealth</a> in Latin America. It is considered an advanced <a href="/wiki/Emerging_market" title="Emerging market">emerging economy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[22]</a></sup> having the twelfth largest <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> in the world by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">nominal</a>, and eighth by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">PPP</a> measures.<sup id="cite_ref-IMF,_October_2015_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF,_October_2015-27">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[24]</a></sup> It is one of the world's major <a href="/wiki/Breadbasket" title="Breadbasket">breadbaskets</a>, being the largest <a href="/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Brazil" title="Coffee production in Brazil">producer of coffee</a> for the last 150 years.<sup id="cite_ref-Neilson102_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Neilson102-29">[25]</a></sup> Brazil is a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> and sometimes considered a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great</a><sup id="cite_ref-SchaeferPoffenbarger2014_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SchaeferPoffenbarger2014-30">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gina_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gina-31">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Burges2016_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Burges2016-32">[28]</a></sup> or a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> in <a href="/wiki/International_relations" title="International relations">international affairs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Burges2016_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Burges2016-32">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gina_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gina-31">[27]</a></sup> On account of its international recognition and influence, the country is subsequently classified as an <a href="/wiki/Emerging_power" title="Emerging power">emerging power</a><sup id="cite_ref-FRIDE_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FRIDE-37">[33]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Potential_superpowers" title="Potential superpowers">potential superpower</a> by several analysts.<sup id="cite_ref-Collecott_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Collecott-38">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DominguezKim2013_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DominguezKim2013-40">[36]</a></sup> Brazil is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercosur" title="Mercosur">Mercosul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">Organization of Ibero-American States</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Portuguese_Language_Countries" title="Community of Portuguese Language Countries">Community of Portuguese Language Countries</a>. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Brazil" title="Name of Brazil">Name of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The word "Brazil" likely comes from the Portuguese word for <a href="/wiki/Caesalpinia_echinata" class="mw-redirect" title="Caesalpinia echinata">brazilwood</a>, a tree that once grew plentifully along the Brazilian coast.<sup id="cite_ref-Fausto1999_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fausto1999-41">[37]</a></sup> In Portuguese, brazilwood is called <i>pau-brasil</i>, with the word <i>brasil</i> commonly given the etymology "red like an ember", formed from <i>brasa</i> ("ember") and the suffix <i>-il</i> (from <i>-iculum</i> or <i>-ilium</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-Vincent2003_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vincent2003-42">[38]</a></sup> As brazilwood produces a deep red dye, it was highly valued by the European textile industry and was the earliest commercially exploited product from Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-Tucker2007_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tucker2007-43">[39]</a></sup> Throughout the 16th century, massive amounts of brazilwood were harvested by <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Brazil" title="Indigenous peoples in Brazil">indigenous peoples</a> (mostly <a href="/wiki/Tupi_people" title="Tupi people">Tupi</a>) along the Brazilian coast, who sold the timber to European traders (mostly Portuguese, but also French) in return for assorted European consumer goods.<sup id="cite_ref-Lee2011_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lee2011-44">[40]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The official Portuguese name of the land, in original Portuguese records, was the "Land of the Holy Cross" (<i>Terra da Santa Cruz</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-Corporation1880_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Corporation1880-45">[41]</a></sup> but European sailors and merchants commonly called it simply the "Land of Brazil" (<i>Terra do Brasil</i>) because of the brazilwood trade.<sup id="cite_ref-Léry1990_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Léry1990-46">[42]</a></sup> The popular appellation eclipsed and eventually supplanted the official Portuguese name. Some early sailors called it the "Land of Parrots".<sup id="cite_ref-Sokolow2003_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sokolow2003-47">[43]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the <a href="/wiki/Guarani_language" title="Guarani language">Guarani language</a>, an official language of <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>, Brazil is called "Pindorama". This was the name the indigenous population gave to the region, meaning "land of the palm trees".<sup id="cite_ref-Herrera-Sobek2012_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Herrera-Sobek2012-48">[44]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Brazil" title="History of Brazil">History of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Brazilian_history" title="Timeline of Brazilian history">Timeline of Brazilian history</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Cabraline_era">Pre-Cabraline era</span></h3> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:325px;max-width:325px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Parque_Nacional_da_Serra_da_Capivara_(31729373313).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Parque_Nacional_da_Serra_da_Capivara_%2831729373313%29.jpg/150px-Parque_Nacional_da_Serra_da_Capivara_%2831729373313%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="225" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Parque_Nacional_da_Serra_da_Capivara_%2831729373313%29.jpg/225px-Parque_Nacional_da_Serra_da_Capivara_%2831729373313%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Parque_Nacional_da_Serra_da_Capivara_%2831729373313%29.jpg/300px-Parque_Nacional_da_Serra_da_Capivara_%2831729373313%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3767" data-file-height="5651"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Cave_painting" title="Cave painting">Cave painting</a> at <a href="/wiki/Serra_da_Capivara_National_Park" title="Serra da Capivara National Park">Serra da Capivara National Park</a>, one of the largest and oldest concentrations of prehistoric sites in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[45]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:169px;max-width:169px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Burian_urn,_AD_1000-1250,_Marajoara_culture_-_AMNH_-_DSC06177_b.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Burian_urn%2C_AD_1000-1250%2C_Marajoara_culture_-_AMNH_-_DSC06177_b.jpg/167px-Burian_urn%2C_AD_1000-1250%2C_Marajoara_culture_-_AMNH_-_DSC06177_b.jpg" decoding="async" width="167" height="223" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Burian_urn%2C_AD_1000-1250%2C_Marajoara_culture_-_AMNH_-_DSC06177_b.jpg/251px-Burian_urn%2C_AD_1000-1250%2C_Marajoara_culture_-_AMNH_-_DSC06177_b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Burian_urn%2C_AD_1000-1250%2C_Marajoara_culture_-_AMNH_-_DSC06177_b.jpg/334px-Burian_urn%2C_AD_1000-1250%2C_Marajoara_culture_-_AMNH_-_DSC06177_b.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3240" data-file-height="4320"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Burial urn, <a href="/wiki/Marajoara_culture" title="Marajoara culture">Marajoara culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/American_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="American Museum of Natural History">American Museum of Natural History</a>. That culture appeared to flourish between 400 AD and 1400 AD, based on archeological studies.<sup id="cite_ref-Mann_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mann-50">[46]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Some of the earliest human remains found in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luzia_Woman" title="Luzia Woman">Luzia Woman</a>, were found in the area of <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Leopoldo" title="Pedro Leopoldo">Pedro Leopoldo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a> and provide evidence of human habitation going back at least 11,000 years.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-LevineCrocitti1999_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LevineCrocitti1999-52">[48]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The earliest <a href="/wiki/Pottery" title="Pottery">pottery</a> ever found in the Western Hemisphere was excavated in the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_basin" title="Amazon basin">Amazon basin</a> of Brazil and <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">radiocarbon dated</a> to 8,000 years ago (6000 BC). The pottery was found near <a href="/wiki/Santar%C3%A9m,_Par%C3%A1" title="Santarém, Pará">Santarém</a> and provides evidence that the tropical forest region supported a complex prehistoric culture.<sup id="cite_ref-Eighth_Millennium_Pottery_from_a_Prehistoric_Shell_Midden_in_the_Brazilian_Amazon_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eighth_Millennium_Pottery_from_a_Prehistoric_Shell_Midden_in_the_Brazilian_Amazon-53">[49]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Marajoara_culture" title="Marajoara culture">Marajoara culture</a> flourished on <a href="/wiki/Maraj%C3%B3" title="Marajó">Marajó</a> in the Amazon delta from 400 CE to 1400 CE, developing sophisticated pottery, <a href="/wiki/Social_stratification" title="Social stratification">social stratification</a>, large populations, <a href="/wiki/Mound_building" class="mw-redirect" title="Mound building">mound building</a>, and complex social formations such as <a href="/wiki/Chiefdom" title="Chiefdom">chiefdoms</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Mann_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mann-50">[46]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Around the time of the Portuguese arrival, the territory of current day Brazil had an estimated indigenous population of 7 million people,<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[50]</a></sup> mostly semi-nomadic, who subsisted on hunting, fishing, gathering, and migrant agriculture. The indigenous population of Brazil comprised several large indigenous ethnic groups (e.g. the <a href="/wiki/Tup%C3%AD_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Tupí people">Tupis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guaran%C3%AD_people" title="Guaraní people">Guaranis</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%AA_peoples" title="Gê peoples">Gês</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arawak_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="Arawak peoples">Arawaks</a>). The Tupí people were subdivided into the <a href="/wiki/Tupiniquim_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Tupiniquim people">Tupiniquins</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tupinamb%C3%A1_people" title="Tupinambá people">Tupinambás</a>, and there were also many subdivisions of the other groups.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevine200331_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevine200331-55">[51]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Before the arrival of the Europeans, the boundaries between these groups and their subgroups were marked by wars that arose from differences in culture, language and moral beliefs.<sup id="cite_ref-Fausto_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fausto-56">[52]</a></sup> These wars also involved large-scale military actions on land and water, with <a href="/wiki/Cannibalism" title="Cannibalism">cannibalistic</a> rituals on <a href="/wiki/Prisoner_of_war" title="Prisoner of war">prisoners of war</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto200078–80_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto200078–80-58">[54]</a></sup> While heredity had some weight, leadership status was more subdued over time, than allocated in succession ceremonies and conventions.<sup id="cite_ref-Fausto_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fausto-56">[52]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">Slavery</a> among the Indians had a different meaning than it had for Europeans, since it originated from a diverse socioeconomic organization, in which asymmetries were translated into <a href="/wiki/Kinship" title="Kinship">kinship</a> relations.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto200050_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto200050-59">[55]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Portuguese_colonization">Portuguese colonization</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Brazil" title="Colonial Brazil">Colonial Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Emboabas" title="War of the Emboabas">War of the Emboabas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Inconfid%C3%AAncia_Mineira" title="Inconfidência Mineira">Inconfidência Mineira</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_(1865%E2%80%931939).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg/220px-Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="142" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg/330px-Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg/440px-Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2775"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_(1865%E2%80%931939).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Representation of the landing of <a href="/wiki/Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral" title="Pedro Álvares Cabral">Pedro Álvares Cabral</a> in <a href="/wiki/Porto_Seguro" title="Porto Seguro">Porto Seguro</a>, 1500. Painting of 1922.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The land now called Brazil was claimed for the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese Empire</a> on 22 April 1500, with the arrival of the Portuguese fleet commanded by <a href="/wiki/Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral" title="Pedro Álvares Cabral">Pedro Álvares Cabral</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Boxer,_p._98_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boxer,_p._98-60">[56]</a></sup> The Portuguese encountered indigenous peoples divided into several tribes, most of whom spoke languages of the <a href="/wiki/Tupi%E2%80%93Guarani" class="mw-redirect" title="Tupi–Guarani">Tupi–Guarani</a> family, and fought among themselves.<sup id="cite_ref-Boxer,_p.&nbsp;100_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boxer,_p._100-61">[57]</a></sup> Though the first settlement was founded in 1532, <a href="/wiki/Colonization" title="Colonization">colonization</a> effectively began in 1534, when King <a href="/wiki/John_III_of_Portugal" title="John III of Portugal">John&nbsp;III of Portugal</a> divided the territory into the fifteen private and autonomous <a href="/wiki/Captaincies_of_Brazil" title="Captaincies of Brazil">Captaincy Colonies of Brazil</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Skidmore,_p.&nbsp;27_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Skidmore,_p._27-63">[59]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>However, the decentralized and unorganized tendencies of the captaincy colonies proved problematic, and in 1549 the Portuguese king restructured them into the <a href="/wiki/Governorate_General_of_Brazil" title="Governorate General of Brazil">Governorate General of Brazil</a> in the city of <a href="/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia" title="Salvador, Bahia">Salvador</a>, which became the capital of a single and centralized Portuguese colony in South America.<sup id="cite_ref-Skidmore,_p.&nbsp;27_63-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Skidmore,_p._27-63">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[60]</a></sup> In the first two centuries of colonization, Indigenous and European groups lived in constant war, establishing <a href="/wiki/Opportunistic" class="mw-redirect" title="Opportunistic">opportunistic</a> alliances in order to gain advantages against each other.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012-67">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[64]</a></sup> By the mid-16th century, <a href="/wiki/Sugar#Sugarcane" title="Sugar">cane sugar</a> had become Brazil's most important export,<sup id="cite_ref-Boxer,_p.&nbsp;100_61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boxer,_p._100-61">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[65]</a></sup> and slaves purchased in <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Africa#Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Slavery in Africa">slave market of Western Africa</a><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[66]</a></sup> (not only those from Portuguese allies of their colonies in <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Angola" title="Portuguese Angola">Angola</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Mozambique" title="Portuguese Mozambique">Mozambique</a>), had become its largest import,<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[67]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[68]</a></sup> to cope with <a href="/wiki/Plantation_economy" title="Plantation economy">plantations</a> of sugarcane, due to increasing international demand for Brazilian sugar.<sup id="cite_ref-Boxer,_p.&nbsp;102_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boxer,_p._102-73">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[70]</a></sup> Portuguese Brazil received more than 2.8 million slaves from Africa between the years of 1500 to 1800.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[71]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes,_1914.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg/220px-Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg/330px-Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg/440px-Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="314"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes,_1914.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Painting showing the arrest of <a href="/wiki/Tiradentes" title="Tiradentes">Tiradentes</a>; he was sentenced to death for his involvement in the best known <a href="/wiki/Inconfid%C3%AAncia_Mineira" title="Inconfidência Mineira">movement for independence</a> in Colonial Brazil. Painting of 1914.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By the end of the 17th century, sugarcane exports began to decline,<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[72]</a></sup> and the discovery of gold by <a href="/wiki/Bandeirantes" title="Bandeirantes">bandeirantes</a> in the 1690s would become the new backbone of the colony's economy, fostering a <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Gold_Rush" title="Brazilian Gold Rush">Brazilian Gold Rush</a><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[73]</a></sup> which attracted thousands of new <a href="/wiki/Settler_colonialism" title="Settler colonialism">settlers</a> to Brazil from Portugal and all Portuguese colonies around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[74]</a></sup> This increased level of immigration in turn caused <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Emboabas" title="War of the Emboabas">some conflicts</a> between newcomers and old settlers.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[75]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Portuguese expeditions known as <a href="/wiki/Bandeirantes" title="Bandeirantes">Bandeiras</a> gradually advanced the Portugal colonial <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tordesillas" title="Treaty of Tordesillas">original frontiers</a> in South America to approximately the current Brazilian borders.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[77]</a></sup> In this era other European powers tried to colonize parts of Brazil, in incursions that the Portuguese had to fight, notably the French <a href="/wiki/France_Antarctique" title="France Antarctique">in Rio during the 1560s</a>, <a href="/wiki/Equinoctial_France" title="Equinoctial France">in Maranhão during the 1610s</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Brazil" title="Dutch Brazil">Dutch in Bahia and Pernambuco</a>, during the <a href="/wiki/Dutch%E2%80%93Portuguese_War" title="Dutch–Portuguese War">Dutch–Portuguese War</a>, after the end of <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Union" title="Iberian Union">Iberian Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[78]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Portuguese colonial administration in Brazil had two objectives that would ensure colonial order and the <a href="/wiki/Monopoly" title="Monopoly">monopoly</a> of Portugal's wealthiest and largest colony: to keep under control and eradicate all forms of <a href="/wiki/Slave_rebellion" title="Slave rebellion">slave rebellion</a> and resistance, such as the <a href="/wiki/Palmares_(quilombo)" title="Palmares (quilombo)">Quilombo of Palmares</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[79]</a></sup> and to repress all movements for <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_administrative_division" title="Autonomous administrative division">autonomy</a> or <a href="/wiki/Independence" title="Independence">independence</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Inconfid%C3%AAncia_Mineira" title="Inconfidência Mineira">Minas Conspiracy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[80]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="United_Kingdom_with_Portugal">United Kingdom with Portugal</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Portugal,_Brazil_and_the_Algarves" title="United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg/260px-Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg/390px-Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg/520px-Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1408" data-file-height="836"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Acclamation of <a href="/wiki/John_VI_of_Portugal" title="John VI of Portugal">King João VI</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Portugal,_Brazil_and_the_Algarves" title="United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, 6 February 1818
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In late 1807, Spanish and Napoleonic forces threatened the security of <a href="/wiki/Continental_Portugal" title="Continental Portugal">continental Portugal</a>, causing <a href="/wiki/John_VI_of_Portugal" title="John VI of Portugal">Prince Regent João</a>, in the name of <a href="/wiki/Maria_I_of_Portugal" title="Maria I of Portugal">Queen Maria I</a>, to move the royal court from <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a> to <a href="/wiki/Transfer_of_the_Portuguese_Court_to_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Transfer of the Portuguese Court to Brazil">Rio de Janeiro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Boxer,_p.&nbsp;213_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boxer,_p._213-85">[81]</a></sup> There they established some of Brazil's first financial institutions, such as its local <a href="/wiki/Stock_exchange" title="Stock exchange">stock exchanges</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[82]</a></sup> and its <a href="/wiki/Banco_do_Brasil" title="Banco do Brasil">National Bank</a>, additionally ending the Portuguese <a href="/wiki/Monopoly" title="Monopoly">monopoly</a> on Brazilian trade and opening Brazil to other nations. In 1809, in retaliation for being forced into exile, the Prince Regent ordered the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_conquest_of_French_Guiana" title="Portuguese conquest of French Guiana">Portuguese conquest of French Guiana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[83]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With the end of the <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_War" title="Peninsular War">Peninsular War</a> in 1814, the courts of Europe demanded that Queen Maria I and Prince Regent João return to Portugal, deeming it unfit for the head of an ancient European monarchy to reside in a <a href="/wiki/Colony" title="Colony">colony</a>. In 1815, to justify continuing to live in Brazil, where the royal court had thrived for six years, the Crown established the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Portugal,_Brazil,_and_the_Algarves" class="mw-redirect" title="United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil, and the Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil, and the Algarves</a>, thus creating a <a href="/wiki/Pluricontinental" class="mw-redirect" title="Pluricontinental">pluricontinental</a> transatlantic monarchic state.<sup id="cite_ref-Mosher2008_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mosher2008-88">[84]</a></sup> However, the leadership in Portugal, resentful of the new status of its larger colony, continued to demand the return of the court to Lisbon (<i>v.</i> <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Revolution_of_1820" title="Liberal Revolution of 1820">Liberal Revolution of 1820</a>). In 1821, acceding to the demands of revolutionaries who had taken the city of <a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Adelman2006_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Adelman2006-89">[85]</a></sup> D. João VI departed for Lisbon. There he swore an oath to the new constitution, leaving his son, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_I_of_Brazil" title="Pedro I of Brazil">Prince Pedro de Alcântara</a>, as Regent of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Brazil" title="Kingdom of Brazil">Kingdom of Brazil</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[86]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independent_empire">Independent empire</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Brazil" title="Independence of Brazil">Independence of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Brazil" title="Empire of Brazil">Empire of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_Independ%C3%AAncia_ou_Morte_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_Independ%C3%AAncia_ou_Morte_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/260px-Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_Independ%C3%AAncia_ou_Morte_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_Independ%C3%AAncia_ou_Morte_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/390px-Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_Independ%C3%AAncia_ou_Morte_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_Independ%C3%AAncia_ou_Morte_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/520px-Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_Independ%C3%AAncia_ou_Morte_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="34130" data-file-height="18254"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_Independ%C3%AAncia_ou_Morte_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Declaration of the <a href="/wiki/War_of_Independence_of_Brazil" title="War of Independence of Brazil">Brazilian independence</a> by Prince Pedro (later Emperor <a href="/wiki/Pedro_I_of_Brazil" title="Pedro I of Brazil">Pedro&nbsp;I</a>) on 7 September 1822.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Tensions between Portuguese and Brazilians increased, and the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Cortes" title="Portuguese Cortes">Portuguese Cortes</a>, guided by the new political regime imposed by the 1820 Liberal Revolution, tried to re-establish Brazil as a colony.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[87]</a></sup> The Brazilians refused to yield, and Prince Pedro decided to stand with them, <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Declaration_of_Independence" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian Declaration of Independence">declaring the country's independence from Portugal</a> on 7 September 1822.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[88]</a></sup> A month later, Prince Pedro was declared the first <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Emperor of Brazil">Emperor of Brazil</a>, with the royal title of Dom <a href="/wiki/Pedro_I_of_Brazil" title="Pedro I of Brazil">Pedro&nbsp;I</a>, resulting in the foundation of the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Brazil" title="Empire of Brazil">Empire of Brazil</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[89]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_War_of_Independence" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian War of Independence">Brazilian War of Independence</a>, which had already begun along this process, spread through the northern, northeastern regions and in <a href="/wiki/Cisplatina" title="Cisplatina">Cisplatina</a> province.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[90]</a></sup> The last Portuguese soldiers surrendered on 8 March 1824;<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[91]</a></sup> Portugal officially recognized Brazil on 29 August 1825.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[92]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 7 April 1831, worn down by years of administrative turmoil and political dissent with both liberal and conservative sides of politics, including an attempt of <a href="/wiki/Confederation_of_the_Equator" title="Confederation of the Equator">republican secession</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto199982–83_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto199982–83-97">[93]</a></sup> and unreconciled to the way that absolutists in Portugal had given in the succession of King John VI, Pedro&nbsp;I went to Portugal to <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Wars" title="Liberal Wars">reclaim his daughter's crown</a>, abdicating the Brazilian throne in favor of his five-year-old son and heir (who thus became the Empire's second monarch, with the royal title of Dom <a href="/wiki/Pedro_II_of_Brazil" title="Pedro II of Brazil">Pedro&nbsp;II</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[94]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg/170px-Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="258" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg/255px-Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg/340px-Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2531" data-file-height="3844"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Pedro_II_of_Brazil" title="Pedro II of Brazil">Pedro II</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_monarchs_of_Brazil" title="List of monarchs of Brazil">Emperor of Brazil</a> between 1831 and 1889.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As the new Emperor could not exert his constitutional powers until he came of age, a <a href="/wiki/Regency_(government)" class="mw-redirect" title="Regency (government)">regency</a> was set up by the National Assembly.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[95]</a></sup> In the absence of a charismatic figure who could represent a moderate face of power, during this period a series of localized rebellions took place, such as the <a href="/wiki/Cabanagem" title="Cabanagem">Cabanagem</a> in <a href="/wiki/Gr%C3%A3o-Par%C3%A1_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Grão-Pará Province">Grão-Pará Province</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mal%C3%AA_Revolt" class="mw-redirect" title="Malê Revolt">Malê Revolt</a> in <a href="/wiki/Salvador_da_Bahia" class="mw-redirect" title="Salvador da Bahia">Salvador da Bahia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Balaiada" title="Balaiada">Balaiada</a> (<a href="/wiki/Maranh%C3%A3o" title="Maranhão">Maranhão</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Sabinada" title="Sabinada">Sabinada</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bahia" title="Bahia">Bahia</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Ragamuffin_War" title="Ragamuffin War">Ragamuffin War</a>, which began in <a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande_do_Sul" title="Rio Grande do Sul">Rio Grande do Sul</a> and was supported by <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Garibaldi" title="Giuseppe Garibaldi">Giuseppe Garibaldi</a>. These emerged from the dissatisfaction of the provinces with the central power, coupled with old and latent social tensions peculiar to a vast, slaveholding and newly independent <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_2,_2.1_to_2.3_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_2,_2.1_to_2.3-100">[96]</a></sup> This period of internal political and social upheaval, which included the <a href="/wiki/Praieira_revolt" title="Praieira revolt">Praieira revolt</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pernambuco" title="Pernambuco">Pernambuco</a>, was overcome only at the end of the 1840s, years after the end of the regency, which occurred with the <a href="/wiki/Dom_Pedro_II#Early_coronation" class="mw-redirect" title="Dom Pedro II">premature coronation of Pedro II</a> in 1841.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999-101">[97]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the last phase of the monarchy, internal political debate centered on the issue of slavery. The <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">Atlantic slave trade</a> was abandoned in 1850,<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[98]</a></sup> as a result of the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">British</a> <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen_Act" title="Aberdeen Act">Aberdeen Act</a>, but only in <a href="/wiki/Lei_%C3%81urea" title="Lei Áurea">May 1888</a> after a long process of internal mobilization and debate for an ethical and legal dismantling of <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Brazil" title="Slavery in Brazil">slavery in the country</a>, was the institution formally abolished.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[99]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The foreign-affairs policies of the monarchy dealt with issues with the countries of the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">Southern Cone</a> with whom Brazil had borders. Long after the <a href="/wiki/Cisplatine_War" title="Cisplatine War">Cisplatine War</a> that resulted in independence for <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[100]</a></sup> Brazil won three international wars during the 58-year reign of Pedro&nbsp;II. These were the <a href="/wiki/Platine_War" title="Platine War">Platine War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Uruguayan_War" title="Uruguayan War">Uruguayan War</a> and the devastating <a href="/wiki/Paraguayan_War" title="Paraguayan War">Paraguayan War</a>, the largest <a href="/wiki/War_effort" title="War effort">war effort</a> in Brazilian history.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_2,_p._83,_and_2.6_&quot;The_Paraguayan_War&quot;_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_2,_p._83,_and_2.6_&quot;The_Paraguayan_War&quot;-106">[102]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although there was no desire among the majority of Brazilians to change the country's <a href="/wiki/Form_of_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Form of government">form of government</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEErmakoff2006189_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEErmakoff2006189-107">[103]</a></sup> on 15 November 1889, in disagreement with the majority of <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Brazilian_Army" title="Imperial Brazilian Army">Army</a> officers, as well as with rural and financial elites (for different reasons), the monarchy was overthrown by a military coup.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[104]</a></sup> 15 November is now <a href="/wiki/Republic_Day" title="Republic Day">Republic Day</a>, a national holiday.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[105]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_republic">Early republic</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/First_Brazilian_Republic" title="First Brazilian Republic">First Brazilian Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vargas_Era#Estado_Novo" title="Vargas Era">Vargas Era §&nbsp;Estado Novo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Second_Brazilian_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Second Brazilian Republic">Second Brazilian Republic</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg/240px-Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg/360px-Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg/480px-Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5799" data-file-height="3574"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i><a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_Republic_(Brazil)" title="Proclamation of the Republic (Brazil)">Proclamation of the Republic</a></i>, 1893, oil on canvas by <a href="/wiki/Benedito_Calixto" title="Benedito Calixto">Benedito Calixto</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The early republican government was nothing more than a military dictatorship, with army dominating affairs both in Rio de Janeiro and in the states. Freedom of the press disappeared and elections were controlled by those in power.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmallman2002end_of_Chapter_1,_from_p._18_&quot;Military_rule&quot;_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmallman2002end_of_Chapter_1,_from_p._18_&quot;Military_rule&quot;-110">[106]</a></sup> Not until 1894, following <a href="/wiki/Encilhamento" title="Encilhamento">an economic</a> crisis and <a href="/wiki/Revolta_da_Armada" title="Revolta da Armada">a military one</a>, did civilians take power, remaining there until October 1930.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmallman200221–26_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmallman200221–26-111">[107]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[109]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>If in relation to its foreign policy, the country in this first republican period maintained a relative balance characterized by a success in resolving border disputes with neighboring countries,<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[110]</a></sup> only broken by the <a href="/wiki/Acre_War" title="Acre War">Acre War</a> (1899–1902) and <a href="/wiki/Brazil_during_World_War_I" title="Brazil during World War I">its involvement</a> in <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> (1914–1918),<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[111]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[113]</a></sup> followed by a failed attempt to exert a prominent role in the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[114]</a></sup> Internally, from the <i>crisis of Encilhamento</i><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[115]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[117]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Revolta_da_Armada" title="Revolta da Armada">Armada Revolts</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[118]</a></sup> a prolonged cycle of financial, political and social instability began until the 1920s, keeping the country besieged by various rebellions, both civilian<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[119]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[121]</a></sup> and military.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[124]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png/220px-50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="190" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png/330px-50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png/440px-50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png 2x" data-file-width="2257" data-file-height="1950"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           In half of the first 100 years of republic, the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army" title="Brazilian Army">Army</a> exercised power directly or through figures like <a href="/wiki/Get%C3%BAlio_Vargas" title="Getúlio Vargas">Getúlio Vargas</a> (center).
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Massarosaw.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Massarosaw.jpg/220px-Massarosaw.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Massarosaw.jpg/330px-Massarosaw.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Massarosaw.jpg/440px-Massarosaw.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1261" data-file-height="915"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Soldiers of the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Expeditionary_Force" title="Brazilian Expeditionary Force">Brazilian Expeditionary Force</a> greet <a href="/wiki/Italian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian people">Italian civilians</a> in <a href="/wiki/Massarosa" title="Massarosa">Massarosa</a>, during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Brazil was the only independent Latin American country to send ground troops to fight in WWII.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Little by little, <a href="/wiki/Rebellions_and_revolutions_in_Brazil#1st_Republican_period_(1889-1930)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rebellions and revolutions in Brazil">a cycle of general instability</a> sparked by these crises undermined the regime to such an extent that in the wake of the murder of his running mate, the defeated opposition presidential candidate <a href="/wiki/Get%C3%BAlio_Vargas" title="Getúlio Vargas">Getúlio Vargas</a>, supported by most of the military, successfully led the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Revolution_of_1930" title="Brazilian Revolution of 1930">October 1930 Coup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[126]</a></sup> Vargas and the military were supposed to assume power temporarily, but instead closed the Congress, extinguished the Constitution, ruled with emergency powers and replaced the states' governors with their own supporters.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[128]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 1930s, three failed attempts to remove Vargas and his supporters from power occurred. The first was the <a href="/wiki/Constitutionalist_Revolution" title="Constitutionalist Revolution">Constitutionalist Revolution</a> in 1932, led by the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="São Paulo (state)">Paulista</a> <a href="/wiki/Oligarchy" title="Oligarchy">oligarchy</a>. The second was a <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_uprising_of_1935" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian uprising of 1935">Communist uprising</a> in November 1935, and the last one a <i>putsch</i> attempt by <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Integralism" title="Brazilian Integralism">local fascists</a> in May 1938.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[131]</a></sup> The 1935 uprising created a security crisis in which the Congress transferred more power to the executive. The 1937 <i>coup d'état</i> resulted in the cancellation of the 1938 election, formalized Vargas as dictator, beginning the <a href="/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Brazil)" class="mw-redirect" title="Estado Novo (Brazil)">Estado Novo</a> era, which was noted for government brutality and censorship of the press.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[132]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Foreign policy during the Vargas years was marked by the antecedents<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (September 2019)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Brazil remained neutral until August 1942, when the country entered on the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">allied side</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[133]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[134]</a></sup> after suffering <a href="/wiki/Submarine_warfare#Atlantic_ocean" title="Submarine warfare">retaliation</a> by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy#Fascist_regime_(1922–1943)" title="Kingdom of Italy">Fascist Italy</a>, in a strategic dispute over the South Atlantic.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[135]</a></sup> In addition to <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Atlantic#South_Atlantic_(May_1942_–_September_1943)" title="Battle of the Atlantic">its participation in the battle of the Atlantic</a>, Brazil also sent an <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Expeditionary_Force" title="Brazilian Expeditionary Force">expeditionary force</a> to fight in the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Campaign_(World_War_II)" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Campaign (World War II)">Italian campaign</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[136]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With the Allied victory in 1945 and the end of the Nazi-fascist regimes in Europe, Vargas's position became unsustainable and he was swiftly overthrown in another military coup, with democracy "reinstated" by the same army that had ended it 15 years earlier.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[137]</a></sup> Vargas committed suicide in August 1954 amid a political crisis, after having returned to power by election in 1950.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[139]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_era">Contemporary era</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Military_dictatorship_in_Brazil" title="Military dictatorship in Brazil">Military dictatorship in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Brazil_since_1985" title="History of Brazil since 1985">History of Brazil since 1985</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Several brief interim governments followed Vargas's suicide.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[140]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Juscelino_Kubitschek" title="Juscelino Kubitschek">Juscelino Kubitschek</a> became president in 1956 and assumed a conciliatory posture towards the <a href="/wiki/Opposition_(politics)" title="Opposition (politics)">political opposition</a> that allowed him to govern without major crises.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[141]</a></sup> The economy and industrial sector grew remarkably,<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[142]</a></sup> but his greatest achievement was the construction of the new capital city of <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Brasília">Brasília</a>, inaugurated in 1960.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[143]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Constru%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Congresso_Nacional_Esplanada_dos_Minist%C3%A9rios_1959-10.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Constru%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Congresso_Nacional_Esplanada_dos_Minist%C3%A9rios_1959-10.jpg/220px-Constru%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Congresso_Nacional_Esplanada_dos_Minist%C3%A9rios_1959-10.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Constru%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Congresso_Nacional_Esplanada_dos_Minist%C3%A9rios_1959-10.jpg/330px-Constru%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Congresso_Nacional_Esplanada_dos_Minist%C3%A9rios_1959-10.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Constru%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Congresso_Nacional_Esplanada_dos_Minist%C3%A9rios_1959-10.jpg/440px-Constru%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Congresso_Nacional_Esplanada_dos_Minist%C3%A9rios_1959-10.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1430" data-file-height="1427"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Construction of the building of <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress of Brazil</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Brasília">Brasília</a>, the new capital, 1959.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas,_1968-04-04.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg/220px-Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="170" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg/330px-Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg/440px-Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg 2x" data-file-width="646" data-file-height="499"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/M41_Walker_Bulldog" title="M41 Walker Bulldog">M41s</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Avenida_Presidente_Vargas" title="Avenida Presidente Vargas">Avenida Presidente Vargas</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_military_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian military government">military government</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Kubitschek's successor, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A2nio_Quadros" title="Jânio Quadros">Jânio Quadros</a>, resigned in 1961 less than a year after taking office.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[144]</a></sup> His vice-president, <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Goulart" title="João Goulart">João Goulart</a>, assumed the presidency, but aroused strong political opposition<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[145]</a></sup> and was <a href="/wiki/1964_Brazilian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1964 Brazilian coup d'état">deposed in April 1964</a> by a coup that resulted in a <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_military_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian military government">military regime</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[146]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The new regime was intended to be transitory<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[147]</a></sup> but gradually closed in on itself and became a full dictatorship with the promulgation of the <a href="/wiki/AI-5" class="mw-redirect" title="AI-5">Fifth Institutional Act</a> in 1968.<sup id="cite_ref-Gaspari_p.35_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gaspari_p.35-152">[148]</a></sup> Oppression was not limited to those who resorted to guerrilla tactics to fight the regime, but also reached institutional opponents, artists, journalists and other members of civil society,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA395_395],_last_paragraph_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA395_395],_last_paragraph-153">[149]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[150]</a></sup> inside and outside the country through the infamous "<a href="/wiki/Operation_Condor" title="Operation Condor">Operation Condor</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA396_396]_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA396_396]-156">[152]</a></sup> Despite its brutality, like other <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian regimes</a>, due to an economic boom, known as an "economic miracle", the regime reached a peak in popularity in the early 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA395_395–97]_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA395_395–97]-157">[153]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Slowly, however, the wear and tear of years of dictatorial power that had not slowed the repression, even after the defeat of the leftist guerrillas,<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[154]</a></sup> plus the inability to deal with the economic crises of the period and popular pressure, made an opening policy inevitable, which from the regime side was led by Generals <a href="/wiki/Ernesto_Geisel" title="Ernesto Geisel">Ernesto Geisel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Golbery_do_Couto_e_Silva" title="Golbery do Couto e Silva">Golbery do Couto e Silva</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_6_&quot;The_military_government_and_the_transition_to_democracy_(1964–1984)&quot;_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_6_&quot;The_military_government_and_the_transition_to_democracy_(1964–1984)&quot;-159">[155]</a></sup> With the enactment of the <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_law#Brazil" title="Amnesty law">Amnesty Law</a> in 1979, Brazil began a slow return to democracy, which was completed during the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999_101-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999-101">[97]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Civilians returned to power in 1985 when <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Sarney" title="José Sarney">José Sarney</a> assumed the presidency. He became unpopular during his tenure through failure to control the economic crisis and <a href="/wiki/Hyperinflation" title="Hyperinflation">hyperinflation</a> he inherited from the military regime.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[156]</a></sup> Sarney's unsuccessful government led to the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_1989" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian presidential election, 1989">election in 1989</a> of the almost-unknown <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Collor_de_Mello" title="Fernando Collor de Mello">Fernando Collor</a>, subsequently impeached by the National Congress in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[157]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Collor was succeeded by his vice-president, <a href="/wiki/Itamar_Franco" title="Itamar Franco">Itamar Franco</a>, who appointed <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Henrique_Cardoso" title="Fernando Henrique Cardoso">Fernando Henrique Cardoso</a> Minister of Finance. In 1994, Cardoso produced a highly successful <a href="/wiki/Plano_Real" title="Plano Real">Plano Real</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[158]</a></sup> that, after decades of failed economic plans made by previous governments attempting to curb hyperinflation, finally stabilized the Brazilian economy.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Epilogue_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Epilogue-163">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[160]</a></sup> Cardoso won the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_1994" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian presidential election, 1994">1994 election</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_1998" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian presidential election, 1998">again in 1998</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[161]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg/220px-Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg/330px-Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg/440px-Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2595" data-file-height="1772"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Ulysses_Guimar%C3%A3es" title="Ulysses Guimarães">Ulysses Guimarães</a> holding the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Constitution of 1988</a> in his hands.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Protesto_no_Congresso_Nacional_do_Brasil,_17_de_junho_de_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Protesto_no_Congresso_Nacional_do_Brasil%2C_17_de_junho_de_2013.jpg/220px-Protesto_no_Congresso_Nacional_do_Brasil%2C_17_de_junho_de_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Protesto_no_Congresso_Nacional_do_Brasil%2C_17_de_junho_de_2013.jpg/330px-Protesto_no_Congresso_Nacional_do_Brasil%2C_17_de_junho_de_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Protesto_no_Congresso_Nacional_do_Brasil%2C_17_de_junho_de_2013.jpg/440px-Protesto_no_Congresso_Nacional_do_Brasil%2C_17_de_junho_de_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="1981"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
