           Protesters climbed the <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress</a> during the massive <a href="/wiki/2013_protests_in_Brazil" title="2013 protests in Brazil">2013 protests</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Peaceful_transition_of_power" title="Peaceful transition of power">peaceful transition of power</a> from Cardoso to his main opposition leader, <a href="/wiki/Luiz_In%C3%A1cio_Lula_da_Silva" title="Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva">Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva</a> (<a href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_2002" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian presidential election, 2002">elected in 2002</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_2006" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian presidential election, 2006">re-elected in 2006</a>), was seen as proof that Brazil had achieved a long-sought political stability.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[162]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[163]</a></sup> However, sparked by indignation and frustrations accumulated over decades from corruption, <a href="/wiki/Police_brutality" title="Police brutality">police brutality</a>, inefficiencies of the political <a href="/wiki/The_Establishment" title="The Establishment">establishment</a> and <a href="/wiki/Public_service" title="Public service">public service</a>, <a href="/wiki/2013_protests_in_Brazil" title="2013 protests in Brazil">numerous peaceful protests</a> erupted in Brazil from the middle of first term of <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a>, who had succeeded Lula after winning election <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_2010" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian presidential election, 2010">in 2010</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[165]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Rousseff <a href="/wiki/Impeachment_of_Dilma_Rousseff" title="Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff">was impeached</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Congress" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian Congress">Brazilian Congress</a> in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-170">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[167]</a></sup> Large street <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_protests_in_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="2015–16 protests in Brazil">protests for and against her</a> took place during the impeachment process.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[168]</a></sup> The charges against her were fueled by political and economic crises along with evidence of involvement with politicians (from all the primary political parties) in several <a href="/wiki/Bribery" title="Bribery">bribery</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tax_evasion" title="Tax evasion">tax evasion</a> schemes.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[170]</a></sup> In 2017, the Supreme Court requested the investigation of 71 Brazilian lawmakers and nine ministers of President <a href="/wiki/Michel_Temer" title="Michel Temer">Michel Temer</a>'s cabinet who were allegedly linked to the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Car_Wash" title="Operation Car Wash">Petrobras corruption scandal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[171]</a></sup> President Temer himself was also accused of <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Brazil" title="Corruption in Brazil">corruption</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[172]</a></sup> According to a 2018 poll, 62% of the population said that corruption was Brazil's biggest problem.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[173]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Starting in 2013, there is a total change in Brazilian politics, with the overthrow of the <a href="/wiki/Left-wing_politics" title="Left-wing politics">left</a> and the rise of conservatism in <a href="/wiki/Right-wing_politics" title="Right-wing politics">right</a>. With the discovery that the <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Brazil)" title="Workers' Party (Brazil)">PT</a> governments have practically gone bankrupt in <a href="/wiki/Petrobras" title="Petrobras">Petrobras</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[174]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Correios" title="Correios">Correios</a><sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[175]</a></sup> and many other state companies, through a great diversion of public funds and the use of their funds to bribe the <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Senate" title="Brazilian Senate">Brazilian Senate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">Judiciary</a>, in addition to the indiscriminate use of <a href="/wiki/National_Bank_for_Economic_and_Social_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="National Bank for Economic and Social Development">BNDES</a> to finance socialist dictatorships in Cuba, Venezuela, Latin America, Africa and the Middle East<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[176]</a></sup> (with Lula and Dilma openly supporting controversial figures such as <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Ch%C3%A1vez" title="Hugo Chávez">Hugo Chávez</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[177]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro" title="Nicolás Maduro">Nicolás Maduro</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[178]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad" title="Mahmoud Ahmadinejad">Mahmoud Ahmadinejad</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[179]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Evo_Morales" title="Evo Morales">Evo Morales</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[180]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[181]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-un" title="Kim Jong-un">Kim Jong-un</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[182]</a></sup> among others), also counting on the attempts of Dilma Roussef to install "Popular Councils" to replace the power of the federal deputies,<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[183]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jair_Bolsonaro" title="Jair Bolsonaro">Jair Bolsonaro</a>, former captain of the army and candidate of the right, is elected.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[184]</a></sup> Through the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Car_Wash" title="Operation Car Wash">Operation Car Wash</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Police_of_Brazil" title="Federal Police of Brazil">Federal Police of Brazil</a> has since acted on the deviations and corruption of the PT and allied parties at that time. In the <a href="/wiki/2018_Brazilian_general_election" title="2018 Brazilian general election">2018 elections</a>, candidate <a href="/wiki/Jair_Bolsonaro" title="Jair Bolsonaro">Jair Bolsonaro</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Social_Liberal_Party_(Brazil)" title="Social Liberal Party (Brazil)">Social Liberal Party</a> (PSL) was elected president, who won in the second round <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Haddad" title="Fernando Haddad">Fernando Haddad</a>, of the <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Brazil)" title="Workers' Party (Brazil)">Workers Party</a> (PT), with the support of 55.13% of the valid votes.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[185]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Brazil" title="Geography of Brazil">Geography of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Brazil_topo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Brazil_topo.jpg/290px-Brazil_topo.jpg" decoding="async" width="290" height="294" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Brazil_topo.jpg/435px-Brazil_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Brazil_topo.jpg/580px-Brazil_topo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="1419"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Brazil_topo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Topographic map of Brazil
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Brazil occupies a large area along the eastern coast of South America and includes much of the continent's interior,<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_6_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_6-190">[186]</a></sup> sharing land borders with <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> to the south; <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a> to the southwest; <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> to the west; <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> to the northwest; and <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">Suriname</a> and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> (French overseas region of <a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a>) to the north. It shares a border with every South American country except <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_20-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-20">[16]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>It also encompasses a number of oceanic <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelagos</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Fernando_de_Noronha" title="Fernando de Noronha">Fernando de Noronha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rocas_Atoll" title="Rocas Atoll">Rocas Atoll</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter_and_Saint_Paul_Archipelago" title="Saint Peter and Saint Paul Archipelago">Saint Peter and Paul Rocks</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Trindade_and_Martim_Vaz" class="mw-redirect" title="Trindade and Martim Vaz">Trindade and Martim Vaz</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_20-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-20">[16]</a></sup> Its size, relief, climate, and natural resources make Brazil geographically diverse.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_6_190-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_6-190">[186]</a></sup> Including its <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic</a> islands, Brazil lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/6th_parallel_north" title="6th parallel north">6°N</a> and <a href="/wiki/34th_parallel_south" title="34th parallel south">34°S</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/28th_meridian_west" title="28th meridian west">28°</a> and <a href="/wiki/74th_meridian_west" title="74th meridian west">74°W</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_20-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-20">[16]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries and outlying territories by total area">fifth largest</a> country in the world, and third largest in the Americas, with a total area of 8,515,767.049&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (3,287,956&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-Official_Area_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Official_Area-191">[187]</a></sup> including 55,455&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (21,411&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) of water.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_20-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-20">[16]</a></sup> It spans four <a href="/wiki/Time_zone" title="Time zone">time zones</a>; from <a href="/wiki/UTC-05" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC-05">UTC−5</a> comprising the state of <a href="/wiki/Acre_(state)" title="Acre (state)">Acre</a> and the westernmost portion of <a href="/wiki/Amazonas_(Brazilian_state)" title="Amazonas (Brazilian state)">Amazonas</a>, to <a href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9204" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC−04">UTC−4</a> in the western states, to <a href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9203" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC−03">UTC−3</a> in the eastern states (the <a href="/wiki/Time_in_Brazil" title="Time in Brazil">national time</a>) and <a href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9202" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC−02">UTC−2</a> in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Brazil" title="List of islands of Brazil">Atlantic islands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-timezones_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timezones-192">[188]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Amanhecer_no_Hercules_--.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Amanhecer_no_Hercules_--.jpg/220px-Amanhecer_no_Hercules_--.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Amanhecer_no_Hercules_--.jpg/330px-Amanhecer_no_Hercules_--.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Amanhecer_no_Hercules_--.jpg/440px-Amanhecer_no_Hercules_--.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Amanhecer_no_Hercules_--.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/List_of_rock_formations" title="List of rock formations">Rock formations</a> and the <i>Dedo de Deus</i> (God's Finger) peak in the background, <a href="/wiki/Serra_dos_%C3%93rg%C3%A3os_National_Park" title="Serra dos Órgãos National Park">Serra dos Órgãos National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Rio de Janeiro state">Rio de Janeiro state</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Brazil is the longest country in the world, spanning 4,395 km (2,731 mi) from north to south. Brazil is also the only country in the world that has the <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">equator</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tropic_of_Capricorn" title="Tropic of Capricorn">Tropic of Capricorn</a> running through it. Brazilian topography is also diverse and includes hills, mountains, plains, highlands, and scrublands. Much of the terrain lies between 200 metres (660&nbsp;ft) and 800 metres (2,600&nbsp;ft) in elevation.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-193">[189]</a></sup> The main upland area occupies most of the southern half of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_193-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-193">[189]</a></sup> The northwestern parts of the plateau consist of broad, rolling terrain broken by low, rounded hills.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_193-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-193">[189]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The southeastern section is more rugged, with a complex mass of ridges and mountain ranges reaching elevations of up to 1,200 metres (3,900&nbsp;ft).<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_193-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-193">[189]</a></sup> These ranges include the <a href="/wiki/Mantiqueira_Mountains" title="Mantiqueira Mountains">Mantiqueira</a> and <a href="/wiki/Espinha%C3%A7o_Mountains" title="Espinhaço Mountains">Espinhaço</a> mountains and the <a href="/wiki/Serra_do_Mar" title="Serra do Mar">Serra do Mar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_193-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-193">[189]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the north, the <a href="/wiki/Guiana_Shield" title="Guiana Shield">Guiana Highlands</a> form a major drainage divide, separating rivers that flow south into the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Basin" class="mw-redirect" title="Amazon Basin">Amazon Basin</a> from rivers that empty into the <a href="/wiki/Orinoco" title="Orinoco">Orinoco River</a> system, in Venezuela, to the north. The highest point in Brazil is the <a href="/wiki/Pico_da_Neblina" title="Pico da Neblina">Pico da Neblina</a> at 2,994 metres (9,823&nbsp;ft), and the lowest is the Atlantic Ocean.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_20-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-20">[16]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil has a dense and complex system of rivers, one of the world's most extensive, with eight major drainage basins, all of which drain into the Atlantic.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_8_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_8-194">[190]</a></sup> Major rivers include the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_River" title="Amazon River">Amazon</a> (the world's second-longest river and the largest in terms of volume of water), the <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_River" title="Paraná River">Paraná</a> and its major tributary the <a href="/wiki/Iguazu_River" title="Iguazu River">Iguaçu</a> (which includes the <a href="/wiki/Iguazu_Falls" title="Iguazu Falls">Iguazu Falls</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Rio_Negro_(Amazon)" title="Rio Negro (Amazon)">Negro</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Francisco_River" title="São Francisco River">São Francisco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xingu_River" title="Xingu River">Xingu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madeira_River" title="Madeira River">Madeira</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tapaj%C3%B3s" title="Tapajós">Tapajós</a> rivers.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_8_194-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_8-194">[190]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Brazil" title="Climate of Brazil">Climate of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg/260px-K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="351" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg/390px-K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg/520px-K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="1296"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Brazil map of <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> zones
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The climate of Brazil comprises a wide range of weather conditions across a large area and varied topography, but most of the country is tropical.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_20-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-20">[16]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen system</a>, Brazil hosts six major climatic subtypes: <a href="/wiki/Desert_climate" title="Desert climate">desert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest_climate" title="Tropical rainforest climate">equatorial</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">tropical</a>, <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semiarid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">subtropical</a>. The different climatic conditions produce environments ranging from <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forests" title="Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests">equatorial rainforests</a> in the north and semiarid deserts in the northeast, to <a href="/wiki/Temperate_coniferous_forest" title="Temperate coniferous forest">temperate coniferous forests</a> in the south and <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_grasslands,_savannas,_and_shrublands" title="Tropical and subtropical grasslands, savannas, and shrublands">tropical savannas</a> in central Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-195">[191]</a></sup> Many regions have starkly different <a href="/wiki/Microclimate" title="Microclimate">microclimates</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-196">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BT_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BT-197">[193]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>An equatorial climate characterizes much of northern Brazil. There is no real <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry season</a>, but there are some variations in the period of the year when most rain falls.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_195-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-195">[191]</a></sup> Temperatures average 25&nbsp;°C (77&nbsp;°F),<sup id="cite_ref-BT_197-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BT-197">[193]</a></sup> with more significant temperature variation between night and day than between seasons.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_196-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-196">[192]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Over central Brazil rainfall is more seasonal, characteristic of a savanna climate.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_196-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-196">[192]</a></sup> This region is as extensive as the Amazon basin but has a very different climate as it lies farther south at a higher altitude.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_195-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-195">[191]</a></sup> In the interior northeast, seasonal rainfall is even more extreme.<sup id="cite_ref-Rain_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rain-198">[194]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The semiarid climatic region generally receives less than 800 millimetres (31.5&nbsp;in) of rain,<sup id="cite_ref-Rain_198-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rain-198">[194]</a></sup> most of which generally falls in a period of three to five months of the year<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[195]</a></sup> and occasionally less than this, creating long periods of drought.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_196-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-196">[192]</a></sup> Brazil's 1877–78 <i><a href="/wiki/Grande_Seca" title="Grande Seca">Grande Seca</a></i> (Great Drought), the worst in Brazil's history,<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[196]</a></sup> caused approximately half a million deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[197]</a></sup> A similarly devastating drought occurred in 1915.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[198]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>South of Bahia, near the coasts, and more southerly most of the state of São Paulo, the distribution of rainfall changes, with rain falling throughout the year.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_195-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-195">[191]</a></sup> The south enjoys subtropical conditions, with cool winters and average annual temperatures not exceeding 18&nbsp;°C (64.4&nbsp;°F);<sup id="cite_ref-BT_197-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BT-197">[193]</a></sup> winter frosts and <a href="/wiki/Snow_in_Brazil" title="Snow in Brazil">snowfall</a> are not rare in the highest areas.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_195-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-195">[191]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_196-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-196">[192]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity_and_environment">Biodiversity and environment</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">Wildlife of Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_Brazil" title="Deforestation in Brazil">Deforestation in Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Conservation_in_Brazil" title="Conservation in Brazil">Conservation in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Jaguar_(Panthera_onca_palustris)_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG/200px-Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="200" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG/300px-Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG/400px-Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3480" data-file-height="3480"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Female <a href="/wiki/Pantanal_jaguar" class="mw-redirect" title="Pantanal jaguar">pantanal jaguar</a> in <a href="/wiki/Piquir%C3%AD_River_(S%C3%A3o_Louren%C3%A7o)" title="Piquirí River (São Lourenço)">Piquirí River</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pantanal" title="Pantanal">Pantanal</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg/200px-Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg/300px-Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg/400px-Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1772" data-file-height="1181"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Golden_lion_tamarin" title="Golden lion tamarin">Golden lion tamarin</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Endemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic">endemic</a> animal of Brazil, in the <a href="/wiki/Po%C3%A7o_das_Antas_Biological_Reserve" title="Poço das Antas Biological Reserve">Poço das Antas Biological Reserve</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Amazon_CIAT_(5).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg/220px-Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg/330px-Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg/440px-Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Amazon_CIAT_(5).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a>, the most biodiverse <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rainforest</a> in the world
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Brazil's large territory comprises different ecosystems, such as the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a>, recognized as having the greatest <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biological diversity</a> in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-WWF_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WWF-203">[199]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Forest" title="Atlantic Forest">Atlantic Forest</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Cerrado" title="Cerrado">Cerrado</a>, sustaining the greatest biodiversity.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-204">[200]</a></sup> In the south, the <a href="/wiki/Araucaria" title="Araucaria">Araucaria</a> pine forest grows under temperate conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_204-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-204">[200]</a></sup> The rich wildlife of Brazil reflects the variety of natural habitats. Scientists estimate that the total number of <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">plant</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">animal species</a> in Brazil could approach four million, mostly invertebrates.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_204-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-204">[200]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Larger mammals include carnivores <a href="/wiki/Cougar" title="Cougar">pumas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaguar" title="Jaguar">jaguars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ocelot" title="Ocelot">ocelots</a>, rare <a href="/wiki/Bush_dog" title="Bush dog">bush dogs</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fox" title="Fox">foxes</a>, and herbivores <a href="/wiki/Peccary" title="Peccary">peccaries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tapir" title="Tapir">tapirs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anteater" title="Anteater">anteaters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sloth" title="Sloth">sloths</a>, <a href="/wiki/Opossum" title="Opossum">opossums</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Armadillo" title="Armadillo">armadillos</a>. <a href="/wiki/Deer" title="Deer">Deer</a> are plentiful in the south, and many species of <a href="/wiki/New_World_monkey" title="New World monkey">New World monkeys</a> are found in the northern <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rain forests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_204-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-204">[200]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[201]</a></sup> Concern for the environment has grown in response to global interest in environmental issues.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_11_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_11-206">[202]</a></sup> Brazil's Amazon Basin is home to an extremely diverse array of fish species, including the <a href="/wiki/Red-bellied_piranha" title="Red-bellied piranha">red-bellied piranha</a>. </p>
      <p>By 2013, Brazil's "dramatic policy-driven reduction in Amazon Basin deforestation" was a "global exception in terms of forest change", according to scientific journal <i><a href="/wiki/Science_(journal)" title="Science (journal)">Science</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-sciencemag_Hansen_20131115_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciencemag_Hansen_20131115-207">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>852</span></sup> From 2003 to 2011, compared to all other countries in the world, Brazil had the "largest decline in annual forest loss", as indicated in the study using high-resolution satellite maps showing global forest cover changes.<sup id="cite_ref-sciencemag_Hansen_20131115_207-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciencemag_Hansen_20131115-207">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>850</span></sup> The annual loss of forest cover decreased from a 2003/2004 record high of more than 40,000 square kilometres (4,000<span style="margin-left:0.2em">×<span style="margin-left:0.1em">10</span></span><s style="display:none">^</s><sup>3</sup>&nbsp;ha; 9.9<span style="margin-left:0.2em">×<span style="margin-left:0.1em">10</span></span><s style="display:none">^</s><sup>6</sup> acres; 15,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) to a 2010/2011 low of under 20,000 square kilometres (2,000<span style="margin-left:0.2em">×<span style="margin-left:0.1em">10</span></span><s style="display:none">^</s><sup>3</sup>&nbsp;ha; 4.9<span style="margin-left:0.2em">×<span style="margin-left:0.1em">10</span></span><s style="display:none">^</s><sup>6</sup> acres; 7,700&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-sciencemag_Hansen_20131115_207-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciencemag_Hansen_20131115-207">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>850</span></sup> reversing widespread deforestation<sup id="cite_ref-sciencemag_Hansen_20131115_207-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciencemag_Hansen_20131115-207">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>852</span></sup> from the 1970s to 2003. </p>
      <p>However, in 2019, when the <a href="/wiki/Bolsonaro_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolsonaro government">Bolsonaro government</a> came to power, the rate of <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_of_the_Amazon_rainforest" title="Deforestation of the Amazon rainforest">deforestation of the Amazon rainforest</a> increased sharply threatening to reach a tipping point after it the forest will collapse, having severe consequences for the world (see <a href="/wiki/Tipping_points_in_the_climate_system" title="Tipping points in the climate system">Tipping points in the climate system</a>) and possibly complicating the trade agreement with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[204]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to a 2008 GreenPeace article, the natural heritage of Brazil is severely threatened by cattle ranching and agriculture, logging, mining, resettlement, oil and gas extraction, over-fishing, wildlife trade, dams and infrastructure, water pollution, <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Brazil" title="Climate change in Brazil">climate change</a>, fire, and invasive species.<sup id="cite_ref-WWF_203-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WWF-203">[199]</a></sup> In many areas of the country, the natural environment is threatened by development.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[205]</a></sup> The construction of highways has opened up previously remote areas for agriculture and settlement; dams have flooded valleys and inundated wildlife habitats; and mines have scarred and polluted the landscape.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_11_206-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_11-206">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[206]</a></sup> At least 70 dams are said to be planned for the Amazon region, including the controversial <a href="/wiki/Belo_Monte_Dam" title="Belo Monte Dam">Belo Monte</a> hydroelectric dam.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[207]</a></sup> In summer 2019, 2 states in Brazil <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_(state)" title="Paraná (state)">Paraná</a> and <a href="/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state)" title="Santa Catarina (state)">Santa Catarina</a> banned <a href="/wiki/Fracking" class="mw-redirect" title="Fracking">fracking</a>, what it is expected to have positive effects on the climate and water quality, because the <a href="/wiki/Shale_gas" title="Shale gas">shale gas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shale_oil" title="Shale oil">shale oil</a> reserves in the state of Parana are the larger in the southern hemisphere.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[209]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2020 the government of Brazil pledged to reduce its annual <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">greenhouse gases</a> emissions by 43% by 2030. It also set as indicative target of reaching carbon neutrality by the year 2060 if the country gets 10 billion dollars per year.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[210]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Brazil" title="Politics of Brazil">Politics of Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_Brazil" title="Federal government of Brazil">Federal government of Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Brazil" title="Elections in Brazil">Elections in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg/220px-Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg/330px-Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg/440px-Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2048"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto" title="Palácio do Planalto">Palácio do Planalto</a> ("Plateau Palace"), the official workplace of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Brazil" title="President of Brazil">President of Brazil</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The form of government is a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratic</a> <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federative</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> The president is both head of state and head of government of the Union and is elected for a four-year term,<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> with the possibility of re-election for a second successive term. The current president is <a href="/wiki/Jair_Bolsonaro" title="Jair Bolsonaro">Jair Bolsonaro</a>. The previous president, <a href="/wiki/Michel_Temer" title="Michel Temer">Michel Temer</a>, replaced <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a> after her <a href="/wiki/Impeachment_of_Dilma_Rousseff" title="Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff">impeachment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-215">[211]</a></sup> The President appoints the <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_State" title="Minister of State">Ministers of State</a>, who assist in government.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> Legislative houses in each political entity are the main source of law in Brazil. The <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress</a> is the Federation's bicameral legislature, consisting of the <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Chamber of Deputies of Brazil">Chamber of Deputies</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Senate of Brazil">Federal Senate</a>. Judiciary authorities exercise jurisdictional duties almost exclusively. Brazil is a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a>, according to the <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a> 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[212]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The political-administrative organization of the Federative Republic of Brazil comprises the Union, the states, the Federal District, and the municipalities.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> The Union, the states, the Federal District, and the municipalities, are the "spheres of government". The <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federation</a> is set on five fundamental principles:<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> sovereignty, citizenship, dignity of human beings, the social values of labor and freedom of enterprise, and political <a href="/wiki/Pluralism_(political_theory)" title="Pluralism (political theory)">pluralism</a>. The classic tripartite branches of government (executive, legislative and judicial under a checks and balances system) are formally established by the Constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> The executive and legislative are organized <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">independently in all three spheres of government</a>, while the judiciary is organized only at the federal and state and Federal District spheres. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg/220px-Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="125" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg/330px-Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg/440px-Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1162"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress</a>, seat of the <a href="/wiki/Legislative_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative branch">legislative branch</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>All members of the executive and legislative branches are directly elected.<sup id="cite_ref-embassy_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-embassy-217">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[215]</a></sup> Judges and other judicial officials are appointed after passing entry exams.<sup id="cite_ref-embassy_217-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-embassy-217">[213]</a></sup> For most of its democratic history, Brazil has had a multi-party system, proportional representation. Voting is compulsory for the literate between 18 and 70 years old and optional for illiterates and those between 16 and 18 or beyond 70.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Together with several smaller parties, four political parties stand out: <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Brazil)" title="Workers' Party (Brazil)">Workers' Party</a> (PT), <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Social_Democracy_Party" title="Brazilian Social Democracy Party">Brazilian Social Democracy Party</a> (PSDB), <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Democratic_Movement" title="Brazilian Democratic Movement">Brazilian Democratic Movement</a> (MDB) and <a href="/wiki/Democrats_(Brazil)" title="Democrats (Brazil)">Democrats</a> (DEM). Fifteen political parties are represented in Congress. It is common for politicians to switch parties, and thus the proportion of congressional seats held by particular parties changes regularly.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[216]</a></sup> Almost all governmental and administrative functions are exercised by authorities and agencies affiliated to the Executive. </p>
      <p>The country has more than 40 active political parties, and only one of them defines itself as a right-wing party (<a href="/wiki/Social_Liberal_Party_(Brazil)" title="Social Liberal Party (Brazil)">PSL</a>), with a clear political imbalance. The country has several far-left parties like <a href="/wiki/Socialism_and_Liberty_Party" title="Socialism and Liberty Party">PSOL</a>, <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Cause_Party" title="Workers' Cause Party">PCO</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Socialist_Workers%27_Party" title="United Socialist Workers' Party">PSTU</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Communist_Party" title="Brazilian Communist Party">PCB</a>, <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Brazil" title="Communist Party of Brazil">PC do B</a>, left parties like <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Brazil)" title="Workers' Party (Brazil)">PT</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Socialist_Party" title="Brazilian Socialist Party">PSB</a>, <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Labour_Party_(Brazil)" title="Democratic Labour Party (Brazil)">PDT</a>, <a href="/wiki/Green_Party_(Brazil)" title="Green Party (Brazil)">PV</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sustainability_Network" title="Sustainability Network">Rede</a> and <a href="/wiki/Solidariedade" title="Solidariedade">Solidariedade</a> and center-left like <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Social_Democracy_Party" title="Brazilian Social Democracy Party">PSDB</a>, <a href="/wiki/Democrats_(Brazil)" title="Democrats (Brazil)">DEM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Party_of_National_Mobilization" title="Party of National Mobilization">PMN</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cidadania" title="Cidadania">Cidadania</a>. Ten parties declare themselves as the center: <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Democratic_Movement" title="Brazilian Democratic Movement">MDB</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_(Brazil,_2006)" title="Liberal Party (Brazil, 2006)">PL</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_(Brazil,_2011)" title="Social Democratic Party (Brazil, 2011)">PSD</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_Labour_Party" title="Christian Labour Party">PTC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_Democracy_(Brazil)" title="Christian Democracy (Brazil)">DC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_of_the_Social_Order" title="Republican Party of the Social Order">PROS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Avante_(political_party)" title="Avante (political party)">Avante</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patriota" title="Patriota">Patriota</a>, <a href="/wiki/Podemos_(Brazil)" title="Podemos (Brazil)">Podemos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Party_of_the_Brazilian_Woman" title="Party of the Brazilian Woman">PMB</a>. Five parties declare themselves as center-right: <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Labour_Party_(current)" title="Brazilian Labour Party (current)">PTB</a>, <a href="/wiki/Progressistas" title="Progressistas">Progressistas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_Christian_Party_(Brazil)" title="Social Christian Party (Brazil)">PSC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Labour_Renewal_Party" title="Brazilian Labour Renewal Party">PRTB</a> and <a href="/wiki/Republicans_(Brazil)" title="Republicans (Brazil)">Republicanos</a>. The only party that claims to be purely liberal, without further consideration, is <a href="/wiki/New_Party_(Brazil)" title="New Party (Brazil)">Novo</a>. When asked about their ideological spectrum, Brazilian parties tend to give obtuse and non-conclusive answers on the subject.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[217]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Brazil" title="Law of Brazil">Law of Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Brazil" title="Law enforcement in Brazil">Law enforcement in Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Brazil" title="Crime in Brazil">Crime in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Supremo_Brasil.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supremo_Brasil.jpg/220px-Supremo_Brasil.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supremo_Brasil.jpg/330px-Supremo_Brasil.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supremo_Brasil.jpg/440px-Supremo_Brasil.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2896" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Supremo_Brasil.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Supreme_Federal_Court_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Federal Court of Brazil">Supreme Federal Court of Brazil</a> serves primarily as the Constitutional Court of the country
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Brazilian law is based on the <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> legal system<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[218]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> concepts prevail over common law practice. Most of Brazilian law is codified, although non-codified statutes also represent a substantial part, playing a complementary role. Court decisions set out interpretive guidelines; however, they are seldom binding on other specific cases. Doctrinal works and the works of academic jurists have strong influence in law creation and in law cases. </p>
      <p>The legal system is based on the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Federal Constitution</a>, promulgated on 5 October 1988, and the fundamental law of Brazil. All other legislation and court decisions must conform to its rules.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[219]</a></sup> As of April&nbsp;2007<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Brazil&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there have been 53 amendments. States have their own constitutions, which must not contradict the Federal Constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[220]</a></sup> Municipalities and the Federal District have "organic laws" (<i lang="pt" title="Portuguese-language text">leis orgânicas</i>), which act in a similar way to constitutions.<sup id="cite_ref-DeffentiBarral2011_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DeffentiBarral2011-225">[221]</a></sup> Legislative entities are the main source of statutes, although in certain matters judiciary and executive bodies may enact legal norms.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> Jurisdiction is administered by the judiciary entities, although in rare situations the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Federal Constitution</a> allows the Federal Senate to pass on legal judgments.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> There are also specialized military, labor, and electoral courts.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> The highest court is the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Federal_Court" title="Supreme Federal Court">Supreme Federal Court</a>. </p>
      <p>This system has been criticized over the last few decades for the slow pace of decision-making. Lawsuits on appeal may take several years to resolve, and in some cases more than a decade elapses before definitive rulings.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[222]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the Supreme Federal Tribunal was the first court in the world to transmit its sessions on television, and also via <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[224]</a></sup> More recently, in December 2009, the Supreme Court adopted <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a> to display items on the day planner of the ministers, to inform the daily actions of the Court and the most important decisions made by them.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[225]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Armed_Forces" title="Brazilian Armed Forces">Brazilian Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:200923ASO_Anderson_Soares_50.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/200923ASO_Anderson_Soares_50.jpg/220px-200923ASO_Anderson_Soares_50.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/200923ASO_Anderson_Soares_50.jpg/330px-200923ASO_Anderson_Soares_50.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/200923ASO_Anderson_Soares_50.jpg/440px-200923ASO_Anderson_Soares_50.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5049" data-file-height="3366"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Air_Force" title="Brazilian Air Force">Brazilian Air Force</a> <a href="/wiki/Saab_JAS_39_Gripen#Brazil" title="Saab JAS 39 Gripen">Saab Gripen NG</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Astros_2020_(14338252946).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg/220px-Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg/330px-Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg/440px-Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2931" data-file-height="2089"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army" title="Brazilian Army">Brazilian Army</a> <a href="/wiki/Astros_II_MLRS" title="Astros II MLRS">Astros 2020</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_(29323273127).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg/220px-GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg/330px-GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg/440px-GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5568" data-file-height="3712"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Navy" title="Brazilian Navy">Brazilian Navy</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Flagship" title="Flagship">flagship</a> <a href="/wiki/PHM_Atl%C3%A2ntico" class="mw-redirect" title="PHM Atlântico">PHM <i>Atlântico</i></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The armed forces of Brazil are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">largest</a> in Latin America by active personnel and the largest in terms of military equipment.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[226]</a></sup> It consists of the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army" title="Brazilian Army">Brazilian Army</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army_Aviation_Command" title="Brazilian Army Aviation Command">Army Aviation Command</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Navy" title="Brazilian Navy">Brazilian Navy</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Marine_Corps" title="Brazilian Marine Corps">Marine Corps</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Naval_Aviation" title="Brazilian Naval Aviation">Naval Aviation</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Air_Force" title="Brazilian Air Force">Brazilian Air Force</a>. Brazil's <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a> policy gives it one of the world's largest military forces, estimated at more than 1.6&nbsp;million <a href="/wiki/Military_Reserve" class="mw-redirect" title="Military Reserve">reservists</a> annually.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[227]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Numbering close to 236,000 active personnel,<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[228]</a></sup> the Brazilian Army has the largest number of armored vehicles in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, including armored transports and <a href="/wiki/Battle_tank" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle tank">tanks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-militarypower1_233-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-militarypower1-233">[229]</a></sup> It is also unique in Latin America for its large, elite forces specializing in unconventional missions, the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Special_Operations_Command" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian Special Operations Command">Brazilian Special Operations Command</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[232]</a></sup> and the versatile Strategic Rapid Action Force, made up of highly mobilized and prepared Special Operations Brigade, <a href="/wiki/Parachute_Infantry_Brigade_(Brazil)" class="mw-redirect" title="Parachute Infantry Brigade (Brazil)">Infantry Brigade Parachutist</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[234]</a></sup> 1st Jungle Infantry Battalion (Airmobile)<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[235]</a></sup> and 12th Brigade Light Infantry (Airmobile)<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[236]</a></sup> able to act anywhere in the country, on short notice, to counter external aggression.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[237]</a></sup> The states' <a href="/wiki/Military_Police_(Brazil)" title="Military Police (Brazil)">Military Police</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Military_Firefighters_Corps" title="Military Firefighters Corps">Military Firefighters Corps</a> are described as an ancillary forces of the Army by the constitution, but are under the control of each state's governor.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil's navy, the second-largest in the Americas, once operated some of the most powerful warships in the world with the two <a href="/wiki/Minas_Geraes-class_battleship" title="Minas Geraes-class battleship"><i>Minas Geraes</i>-class</a> <a href="/wiki/Dreadnought" title="Dreadnought">dreadnoughts</a>, which sparked a <a href="/wiki/South_American_dreadnought_race" title="South American dreadnought race">South American dreadnought race</a> between Argentina, Brazil, and Chile.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[238]</a></sup> Today, it is a <a href="/wiki/Green-water_navy" title="Green-water navy">green water</a> force and has a group of specialized elite in retaking ships and naval facilities, <a href="/wiki/GRUMEC" title="GRUMEC">GRUMEC</a>, unit specially trained to protect Brazilian oil platforms along its coast.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[239]</a></sup> It is the only navy in Latin America that operates an <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carrier</a>, <a href="/wiki/PHM_Atlantico" class="mw-redirect" title="PHM Atlantico">PHM Atlantico</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[240]</a></sup> and one of the ten navies of the world to operate one.<sup id="cite_ref-militarypower1_233-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-militarypower1-233">[229]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Air Force is the largest in Latin America and has about 700 manned aircraft in service and effective about 67,000 personnel.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[241]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil has not been invaded since 1865 during the <a href="/wiki/Paraguayan_War" title="Paraguayan War">Paraguayan War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[242]</a></sup> Additionally, Brazil has no contested territorial disputes with any of its neighbors<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[243]</a></sup> and neither does it have rivalries, like Chile and Bolivia have with each other.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[244]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[245]</a></sup> The Brazilian military has also three times intervened militarily to overthrow the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Government of Brazil">Brazilian government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-revistaepoca.globo.com_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-revistaepoca.globo.com-250">[246]</a></sup> It has built a tradition of participating in UN <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> missions such as in <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">East Timor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_African_Republic" title="Central African Republic">Central African Republic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[247]</a></sup> Brazil signed the UN <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[248]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_policy">Foreign policy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Brazil" title="Foreign relations of Brazil">Foreign relations of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Brasilia-2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Brasilia-2.jpg/220px-Brasilia-2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Brasilia-2.jpg/330px-Brasilia-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Brasilia-2.jpg/440px-Brasilia-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4101" data-file-height="2724"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Brasilia-2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Itamaraty_Palace" title="Itamaraty Palace">Itamaraty Palace</a>, the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Brazil)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Brazil)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Brazil's international relations are based on Article 4 of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Federal Constitution</a>, which establishes <a href="/wiki/Non-interventionism" title="Non-interventionism">non-intervention</a>, <a href="/wiki/Self-determination" title="Self-determination">self-determination</a>, <a href="/wiki/Internationalism_(politics)" title="Internationalism (politics)">international cooperation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Peacebuilding" title="Peacebuilding">peaceful settlement of conflicts</a> as the guiding principles of Brazil's relationship with other countries and multilateral organizations.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[249]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the Constitution, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Brazil" title="President of Brazil">President</a> has ultimate authority over foreign policy, while the <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">Congress</a> is tasked with reviewing and considering all diplomatic nominations and <a href="/wiki/Treaty" title="Treaty">international treaties</a>, as well as legislation relating to Brazilian foreign policy.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[250]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil's foreign policy is a by-product of the country's position as a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, a leader among <a href="/wiki/Developing_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Developing countries">developing countries</a>, and an emerging <a href="/wiki/World_power" class="mw-redirect" title="World power">world power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[251]</a></sup> Brazilian foreign policy has generally been based on the principles of <a href="/wiki/Multilateralism" title="Multilateralism">multilateralism</a>, peaceful dispute settlement, and <a href="/wiki/Non-interventionism" title="Non-interventionism">non-intervention</a> in the affairs of other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[252]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil is a founding member state of the <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Portuguese_Language_Countries" title="Community of Portuguese Language Countries">Community of Portuguese Language Countries</a> (CPLP), also known as the Lusophone Commonwealth, an international organization and political association of <a href="/wiki/Lusophone" title="Lusophone">Lusophone</a> nations across four continents, where <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a> is an official language. </p>
      <p>An increasingly well-developed tool of Brazil's foreign policy is providing aid as a donor to other developing countries.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-257">[253]</a></sup> Brazil does not just use its growing economic strength to provide financial aid, but it also provides high levels of expertise and most importantly of all, a quiet non-confrontational diplomacy to improve governance levels.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-257">[253]</a></sup> Total aid is estimated to be around $1&nbsp;billion per year, which includes:<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_257-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-257">[253]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG/330px-Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG" decoding="async" width="330" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG/495px-Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG/660px-Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1425" data-file-height="625"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil" title="List of diplomatic missions in Brazil">Diplomatic missions of Brazil</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li>technical cooperation of around $480&nbsp;million ($30&nbsp;million in 2010 provided directly by the Brazilian Cooperation Agency (ABC));</li> 
       <li>estimated $450&nbsp;million for in-kind expertise provided by Brazilian institutions specializing in technical cooperation.</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>In addition, Brazil manages a peacekeeping mission in <a href="/wiki/2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="2010 Haiti earthquake">Haiti</a> ($350&nbsp;million) and makes in-kind contributions to the <a href="/wiki/World_Food_Programme" title="World Food Programme">World Food Programme</a> ($300&nbsp;million).<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_257-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-257">[253]</a></sup> This is in addition to humanitarian assistance and contributions to multilateral development agencies. The scale of this aid places it on par with China and India.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_257-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-257">[253]</a></sup> The Brazilian South-South aid has been described as a "global model in waiting."<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[254]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement_and_crime">Law enforcement and crime</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Brazil" title="Law enforcement in Brazil">Law enforcement in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Brazil" title="Crime in Brazil">Crime in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:COT_(6883689782).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/COT_%286883689782%29.jpg/220px-COT_%286883689782%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/COT_%286883689782%29.jpg/330px-COT_%286883689782%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/COT_%286883689782%29.jpg/440px-COT_%286883689782%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4318" data-file-height="3205"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:COT_(6883689782).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Field agents of the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Police_of_Brazil" title="Federal Police of Brazil">Federal Police</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Comando_de_Opera%C3%A7%C3%B5es_T%C3%A1ticas" title="Comando de Operações Táticas">Tactical Operations Command</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In Brazil, the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Constitution</a> establishes five different police agencies for law enforcement: <a href="/wiki/Federal_Police_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal Police Department">Federal Police Department</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_Highway_Police_(Brazil)" title="Federal Highway Police (Brazil)">Federal Highway Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_Railroad_Police" title="Federal Railroad Police">Federal Railroad Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_Police_(Brazil)" title="Military Police (Brazil)">Military Police</a> and <a href="/wiki/Civil_Police_(Brazil)" title="Civil Police (Brazil)">Civil Police</a>. Of these, the first three are affiliated with federal authorities and the last two are subordinate to state governments. All police forces are the responsibility of the executive branch of any of the federal or state powers.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Public_Security_Force" title="National Public Security Force">National Public Security Force</a> also can act in public disorder situations arising anywhere in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[255]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The country still has above-average levels of violent crime and particularly high levels of gun violence and homicide. In 2012, the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO) estimated the number of 32 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants, one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_intentional_homicide_rate" title="List of countries by intentional homicide rate">highest rates of homicide of the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[256]</a></sup> The number considered tolerable by the WHO is about 10 homicides per 100,000 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[257]</a></sup> In 2018, Brazil had a record 63,880 murders.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[258]</a></sup> However, there are differences between the crime rates in the <a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">Brazilian states</a>. While in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="São Paulo (state)">São Paulo</a> the homicide rate registered in 2013 was 10.8 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants, in <a href="/wiki/Alagoas" title="Alagoas">Alagoas</a> it was 64.7 homicides per 100,000 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[259]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil also has high levels of incarceration and the third largest prison population in the world (behind only <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>), with an estimated total of approximately 700,000 prisoners around the country (June 2014), an increase of about 300% compared to the index registered in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[260]</a></sup> The high number of prisoners eventually overloaded the Brazilian prison system, leading to a shortfall of about 200,000 accommodations.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[261]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">States of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Brazil" title="Municipalities of Brazil">Municipalities of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Brazil" title="Regions of Brazil">Regions of Brazil</a>
      </div>

           </div>

            <i><a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">French Guiana</span></a></i>
