           </div> 
           <div style="position:absolute; left:126px; top:248px">
            <i><a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Paraguay</span></a></i>
           </div> 
           <div style="position:absolute; left:14px; top:164px">
            <i><a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Peru</span></a></i>
           </div> 
           <div style="position:absolute; left:154px; top:12px">
            <i><a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Suriname</span></a></i>
           </div> 
           <div style="position:absolute; left:152px; top:336px">
            <i><a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Uruguay</span></a></i>
           </div> 
           <div style="position:absolute; left:74px; top:4px">
            <i><a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Venezuela</span></a></i>
           </div> 
          </div><a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">States of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Brazil" title="Regions of Brazil">Regions of Brazil</a> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>Brazil is a federation composed of 26 <a href="/wiki/Federated_state" title="Federated state">states</a>, one <a href="/wiki/Federal_district" title="Federal district">federal district</a>, and the 5570 <a href="/wiki/Municipality" title="Municipality">municipalities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> States have autonomous administrations, collect their own taxes and receive a share of taxes collected by the Federal government. They have a governor and a unicameral legislative body elected directly by their voters. They also have independent Courts of Law for common justice. Despite this, states have much less autonomy to create their own laws than in the United States. For example, criminal and civil laws can be voted by only the federal bicameral Congress and are uniform throughout the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The states and the federal district may be grouped into regions: <a href="/wiki/Northern_Region,_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Region, Brazil">Northern</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Northeast Region, Brazil">Northeast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central-West_Region,_Brazil" title="Central-West Region, Brazil">Central-West</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Southeast Region, Brazil">Southeast</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Region,_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Southern Region, Brazil">Southern</a>. The Brazilian regions are merely geographical, not political or administrative divisions, and they do not have any specific form of government. Although defined by law, Brazilian regions are useful mainly for statistical purposes, and also to define the distribution of federal funds in development projects. </p>
      <p>Municipalities, as the states, have autonomous administrations, collect their own taxes and receive a share of taxes collected by the Union and state government.<sup id="cite_ref-Constituição_22-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constituição-22">[18]</a></sup> Each has a mayor and an elected legislative body, but no separate Court of Law. Indeed, a Court of Law organized by the state can encompass many municipalities in a single justice administrative division called <i><a href="/wiki/Comarca" title="Comarca">comarca</a></i> (county). </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Brazil" title="Economy of Brazil">Economy of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_real" title="Brazilian real">Brazilian real</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Brazil" title="Agriculture in Brazil">Agriculture in Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mining_in_Brazil" title="Mining in Brazil">Mining in Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Industry_in_Brazil" title="Industry in Brazil">Industry in Brazil</a>
      </div>

        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ronodon%C3%B3polis_colheita_soja_(Roosevelt_Pinheiro)_28mar09.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Soybean" title="Soybean">Soybean</a> crop in <a href="/wiki/Rondon%C3%B3polis" title="Rondonópolis">Rondonópolis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso" title="Mato Grosso">Mato Grosso</a>. Brazil is the second largest agricultural exporter in the world. The country is a major exporter of soy, maize, sugar, coffee, tobacco, cotton and fruit juices, among other agricultural products.<sup id="cite_ref-exportaçãoagrícola_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-exportaçãoagrícola-266">[262]</a></sup>

       </div>
      </div>

        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cal%C3%A7ados_Beira_Rio.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Cal%C3%A7ados_Beira_Rio.JPG/220px-Cal%C3%A7ados_Beira_Rio.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Cal%C3%A7ados_Beira_Rio.JPG/330px-Cal%C3%A7ados_Beira_Rio.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Cal%C3%A7ados_Beira_Rio.JPG/440px-Cal%C3%A7ados_Beira_Rio.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736"></a>

          <a href="/wiki/File:Cal%C3%A7ados_Beira_Rio.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Shoe factory in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil is the 4th largest producer in the world, being an exporter of quality shoes
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Brazil is the largest national economy in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">world's ninth largest economy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">eighth largest</a> in <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP) according to 2018 estimates. Brazil has a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> with abundant natural resources. After rapid growth in preceding decades, the country <a href="/wiki/2014%E2%80%932016_Brazilian_economic_recession" class="mw-redirect" title="2014–2016 Brazilian economic recession">entered an ongoing recession in 2014</a> amid a political corruption scandal and nationwide protests. </p>
      <p>Its <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">Gross domestic product</a> (PPP) per capita was $15,919 in 2017<sup id="cite_ref-imf_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf-267">[263]</a></sup> putting Brazil in the 77th position according to IMF data. Active in <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agricultural</a>, mining, manufacturing and <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service sectors</a> Brazil has a labor force of over 107 million (ranking 6th worldwide) and unemployment of 6.2% (ranking 64th worldwide).<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Econ_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Econ-268">[264]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The country has been expanding its presence in international financial and <a href="/wiki/Commodity_market" title="Commodity market">commodities markets</a>, and is one of a group of four emerging economies called the <a href="/wiki/BRIC" title="BRIC">BRIC countries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[265]</a></sup> Brazil has been the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Brazil" title="Coffee production in Brazil">producer of coffee</a> for the last 150 years.<sup id="cite_ref-Neilson102_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Neilson102-29">[25]</a></sup> The country is a major exporter of soy, iron ore, pulp (cellulose), maize, beef, chicken meat, soybean meal, sugar, coffee, tobacco, cotton, orange juice, footwear, airplanes, cars, vehicle parts, gold, ethanol, semi-finished iron, among other products.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[266]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[267]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil's diversified economy includes agriculture, industry, and a wide range of services.<sup id="cite_ref-BansalPhatak2009_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BansalPhatak2009-272">[268]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Brazil" title="Agriculture in Brazil">Agriculture</a> and allied sectors like <a href="/wiki/Forestry" title="Forestry">forestry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Logging" title="Logging">logging</a> and fishing accounted for 5.1% of the <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_GDP_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_GDP-273">[269]</a></sup> Brazil is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_producing_countries_of_agricultural_commodities" title="List of largest producing countries of agricultural commodities">largest producer</a> of sugarcane, soy, coffee, orange, <a href="/wiki/Guaran%C3%A1" class="mw-redirect" title="Guaraná">guaraná</a>, <a href="/wiki/A%C3%A7a%C3%AD" class="mw-redirect" title="Açaí">açaí</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazil_nut" title="Brazil nut">Brazil nut</a>; is one of the top 5 producers of <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a>, <a href="/wiki/Papaya" title="Papaya">papaya</a>, tobacco, pineapple, banana, cotton, beans, coconut, watermelon and lemon; is one of the top 10 world producers of <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">cocoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cashew" title="Cashew">cashew</a>, avocado, tangerine, <a href="/wiki/Persimmon" title="Persimmon">persimmon</a>, mango, <a href="/wiki/Guava" title="Guava">guava</a>, rice, <a href="/wiki/Sorghum" title="Sorghum">sorghum</a> and tomato; and is one of the top 15 world producers of grape, apple, melon, peanut, <a href="/wiki/Common_fig" title="Common fig">fig</a>, peach, onion, <a href="/wiki/Palm_oil" title="Palm oil">palm oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_rubber" title="Natural rubber">natural rubber</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[a]</a></sup> The country also produces large quantities of potato,<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[301]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[302]</a></sup> carrot,<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[303]</a></sup> strawberry,<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[304]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yerba_mate" title="Yerba mate">yerba mate</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[305]</a></sup> wheat, among others. Part of the production is exported, and another part goes to the domestic market. </p>
      <p>In the production of animal proteins, Brazil is today one of the largest countries in the world. In 2019, the country was the world's largest exporter of chicken meat.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[306]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[307]</a></sup> It was also the second largest producer of beef,<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[308]</a></sup> the world's third largest producer of milk,<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[309]</a></sup> the world's fourth largest producer of pork<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[310]</a></sup> and the seventh largest producer of eggs in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[311]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the mining sector, Brazil stands out in the extraction of <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a> (where it is the second world exporter), copper, gold, <a href="/wiki/Bauxite" title="Bauxite">bauxite</a> (one of the 5 largest producers in the world), <a href="/wiki/Manganese" title="Manganese">manganese</a> (one of the 5 largest producers in the world), <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a> (one of the largest producers in the world), <a href="/wiki/Niobium" title="Niobium">niobium</a> (concentrates 98% of reserves known to the world) and <a href="/wiki/Nickel" title="Nickel">nickel</a>. In terms of precious stones, Brazil is the world's largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Amethyst" title="Amethyst">amethyst</a>, <a href="/wiki/Topaz" title="Topaz">topaz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agate" title="Agate">agate</a> and one of the main producers of <a href="/wiki/Tourmaline" title="Tourmaline">tourmaline</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emerald" title="Emerald">emerald</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aquamarine_(gemstone)" class="mw-redirect" title="Aquamarine (gemstone)">aquamarine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Garnet" title="Garnet">garnet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[312]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[313]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[314]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[315]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[316]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[317]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Industry_in_Brazil" title="Industry in Brazil">Industry in Brazil</a> – from automobiles, steel and <a href="/wiki/Petrochemical" title="Petrochemical">petrochemicals</a> to computers, aircraft and <a href="/wiki/Durable_good" title="Durable good">consumer durables</a> – accounted for 30.8% of the gross domestic product.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_GDP_273-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_GDP-273">[269]</a></sup> Industry is highly concentrated in metropolitan São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, <a href="/wiki/Campinas" title="Campinas">Campinas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto_Alegre" title="Porto Alegre">Porto Alegre</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GiordanoLanzafame2005_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GiordanoLanzafame2005-323">[318]</a></sup> Brazil has become the fourth largest car market in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[319]</a></sup> Major export products include aircraft, electrical equipment, automobiles, <a href="/wiki/Ethanol_fuel" title="Ethanol fuel">ethanol</a>, textiles, footwear, iron ore, steel, coffee, orange juice, soybeans and <a href="/wiki/Corned_beef" title="Corned beef">corned beef</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[320]</a></sup> In total, Brazil ranks 23rd worldwide in <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">value of exports</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/Food_industry" title="Food industry">food industry</a>, in 2019, Brazil was the second largest exporter of processed foods in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[321]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[322]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[323]</a></sup> In 2016, the country was the 2nd largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Pulp_(paper)" title="Pulp (paper)">pulp</a> in the world and the 8th producer of paper.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[324]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[325]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[326]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Footwear_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Footwear industry">footwear industry</a>, in 2019, Brazil ranked 4th among world producers.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[327]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[328]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[329]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[330]</a></sup> In 2019, the country was the 8th producer of vehicles and the 9th producer of steel in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[331]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[332]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[333]</a></sup> In 2018, the <a href="/wiki/Chemical_industry" title="Chemical industry">chemical industry</a> of Brazil was the 8th in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[334]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[335]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[336]</a></sup> Although it was among the 5 largest world producers in 2013, Brazil's textile industry is very little integrated into world trade.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[337]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The tertiary sector (trade and services) represented 75.8% of the country's GDP in 2018, according to the IBGE. The service sector was responsible for 60% of GDP and trade for 13%. It covers a wide range of activities: commerce, accommodation and catering, transport, communications, financial services, real estate activities and services provided to businesses, public administration (urban cleaning, sanitation, etc.) and other services such as education, social and health services, research and development, sports activities, etc., since it consists of activities complementary to other sectors. <sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[338]</a></sup> <sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[339]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Micro and small businesses represent 30% of the country's GDP. In the commercial sector, for example, they represent 53% of the GDP within the activities of the sector.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[340]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2017, the number of people employed in commercial activities in Brazil was 10.2 million people (74.3% in retail trade, 17.0% in wholesale trade and 8.7% in trade of vehicles, parts and motorcycles). The number of commercial enterprises was 1.5 million and the number of stores 1.7 million. Business activity in the country generated R $ 3.4 trillion in net operating income (gross income minus deductions, such as cancellations, discounts and taxes) and R $ 583.7 billion in gross value added. The trade margin (defined as the difference between net income from resale and cost of goods sold) reached R $ 765.1 billion in 2017. Of this total, retail was responsible for 56.4%, the wholesale trade 36.0% and trade in vehicles, spare parts and motorcycles 7.6%. In 2017 net operating income, retail trade accounted for 45.5%, wholesale trade 44.6% and automotive sector with 9.9%. Among the commercial activity groups, Hypermarkets and Supermarkets have 12.5%; the wholesale trade in fuels and lubricants represented 11.3%; retail and wholesale trade in food, beverages and tobacco accounted for 4.8% and 8.4% respectively; trade in motor vehicles, 6.1%; wholesale trade in machinery, apparatus and equipment, including information and communication technologies, accounted for 3.7%. <sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[341]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil pegged its currency, the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_real" title="Brazilian real">real</a>, to the U.S. dollar in 1994. However, after the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">East Asian financial crisis</a>, the <a href="/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis" title="1998 Russian financial crisis">Russian default</a> in 1998<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[342]</a></sup> and the series of adverse financial events that followed it, the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Brazil" title="Central Bank of Brazil">Central Bank of Brazil</a> temporarily changed its <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a> to a <a href="/wiki/Managed_float_regime" title="Managed float regime">managed float regime</a><sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[343]</a></sup> scheme while undergoing a <a href="/wiki/Currency_crisis" title="Currency crisis">currency crisis</a>, until definitively changing the exchange regime to <a href="/wiki/Free-float" class="mw-redirect" title="Free-float">free-float</a> in January 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[344]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil received an <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> (IMF) rescue package in mid-2002 of $30.4&nbsp;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[345]</a></sup> a record sum at the time. Brazil's central bank repaid the IMF loan in 2005, although it was not due to be repaid until 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[346]</a></sup> One of the issues the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Brazil" title="Central Bank of Brazil">Central Bank of Brazil</a> recently dealt with was an excess of <a href="/wiki/Speculation" title="Speculation">speculative</a> short-term capital inflows to the country, which may have contributed to a fall in the value of the U.S. dollar against the real during that period.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[347]</a></sup> Nonetheless, <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> (FDI), related to long-term, less speculative investment in production, is estimated to be $193.8&nbsp;billion for 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[348]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">Inflation</a> monitoring and control currently plays a major part in the Central bank's role in setting short-term <a href="/wiki/Interest_rate" title="Interest rate">interest rates</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a> measure.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[349]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Between 1993 and 2010, 7012 <a href="/wiki/Mergers_and_acquisitions" title="Mergers and acquisitions">mergers and acquisitions</a> with a total known value of $707&nbsp;billion with the involvement of Brazilian firms were announced.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[350]</a></sup> The year 2010 was a new record in terms of value with US$115&nbsp;billion in transactions. The largest transaction with involvement of Brazilian companies was the <a href="/wiki/Vale_(mining_company)" class="mw-redirect" title="Vale (mining company)">Cia. Vale do Rio Doce</a> acquisition of <a href="/wiki/Vale_Inco" class="mw-redirect" title="Vale Inco">Inco</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Tender_offer" title="Tender offer">tender offer</a> valued at US$18.9&nbsp;billion. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Brazil" title="Corruption in Brazil">Corruption</a> costs Brazil almost $41&nbsp;billion a year alone in 2010, with 69.9% of the country's firms identifying the issue as a major constraint in successfully penetrating the global market.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[351]</a></sup> Local government corruption is so prevalent that voters perceive it as a problem only if it surpasses certain levels, and only if a local media e.g. a radio station is present to divulge the findings of corruption charges.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[352]</a></sup> Initiatives, like this exposure, strengthen awareness which is indicated by the Transparency International's <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>; ranking Brazil 69th out of 178 countries in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[353]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power" title="Purchasing power">purchasing power</a> in Brazil is eroded by the so-called <a href="/wiki/Brazil_cost" title="Brazil cost">Brazil cost</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-brcost_359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brcost-359">[354]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil also has a large <a href="/wiki/Cooperative" title="Cooperative">cooperative</a> sector that provides 50% of the food in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[355]</a></sup> The world's largest healthcare cooperative <a href="/wiki/Unimed_(organization)" title="Unimed (organization)">Unimed</a> is also located in Brazil, and accounts for 32% of the healthcare insurance market in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[356]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Brazil" title="Energy in Brazil">Energy in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Energia_Eolica.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Energia_Eolica.jpg/220px-Energia_Eolica.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Energia_Eolica.jpg/330px-Energia_Eolica.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Energia_Eolica.jpg/440px-Energia_Eolica.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3467" data-file-height="2554"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Energia_Eolica.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Wind_farm" title="Wind farm">Wind farm</a> in <a href="/wiki/Parna%C3%ADba" title="Parnaíba">Parnaíba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piau%C3%AD" title="Piauí">Piauí</a>. Brazil is one of the 10 largest producers of wind energy in the world
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif/220px-Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif/330px-Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif/440px-Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1067"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Pirapora Solar complex, the largest in Brazil and Latin America with 321 MW
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Brazil is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_primary_energy_consumption_and_production" title="List of countries by total primary energy consumption and production">tenth largest</a> energy consumer with much of its energy coming from <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable sources</a>, particularly <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectricity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethanol" title="Ethanol">ethanol</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Itaipu_Dam" title="Itaipu Dam">Itaipu Dam</a> is the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectric plant</a> by energy generation,<sup id="cite_ref-SchmidtOnyango2011_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SchmidtOnyango2011-362">[357]</a></sup> and the country has other large plants like <a href="/wiki/Belo_Monte_Dam" title="Belo Monte Dam">Belo Monte</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tucuru%C3%AD_Dam" title="Tucuruí Dam">Tucuruí</a>. The first car with an ethanol engine was produced in 1978 and the first airplane engine running on ethanol in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-OECDDevelopment2001_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDDevelopment2001-363">[358]</a></sup> In total electricity generation, in 2019 Brazil reached 170,000 megawatts of installed capacity, more than 75% from renewable sources (the majority, hydroelectric plants).<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[359]</a></sup> Brazil is one of the 5 largest hydroelectric energy producers in the world (2nd place in 2017).<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[360]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of September&nbsp;2020,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag ref" style="display:none;"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ons.org.br/paginas/conhecimento/acervo-digital/documentos-e-publicacoes">[ref]</a></sup> according to ONS, total installed capacity of <a href="/wiki/Wind_power" title="Wind power">wind power</a> was 16.3 GW, with average <a href="/wiki/Capacity_factor" title="Capacity factor">capacity factor</a> of 58%.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[361]</a></sup> While the world average wind production capacity factors is 24.7%, there are areas in Northern Brazil, specially in Bahia State, where some wind farms record with average capacity factors over 60%;<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[362]</a></sup> the average capacity factor in the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Northeast Region, Brazil">Northeast Region</a> is 45% in the coast and 49% in the interior.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[363]</a></sup> In 2019, wind energy represented 9% of the energy generated in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[364]</a></sup> In 2019, it was estimated that the country had an estimated wind power generation potential of around 522 GW (this, only onshore), enough energy to meet three times the country's current demand.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[366]</a></sup> Brazil is one of the 10 largest wind energy producers in the world (8th place in 2019, with 2.4% of world production).<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[367]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[368]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of September&nbsp;2020,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag ref" style="display:none;"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ons.org.br/paginas/conhecimento/acervo-digital/documentos-e-publicacoes">[ref]</a></sup> according to ONS, total installed capacity of <a href="/wiki/Photovoltaic_solar" class="mw-redirect" title="Photovoltaic solar">photovoltaic solar</a> was 6.9 GW, with average <a href="/wiki/Capacity_factor" title="Capacity factor">capacity factor</a> of 23%. Some of the most <a href="/wiki/Solar_irradiance" title="Solar irradiance">irradiated</a> Brazilian States are Minas Gerais, Bahia and Goiás.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[369]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[370]</a></sup> In 2019, solar power represented 1.27% of the energy generated in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[371]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Recent oil discoveries in the <a href="/wiki/Pre-salt_layer" title="Pre-salt layer">pre-salt layer</a> have opened the door for a large increase in oil production.<sup id="cite_ref-BrainardMartinez-Diaz2009_377-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BrainardMartinez-Diaz2009-377">[372]</a></sup> The governmental agencies responsible for the energy policy are the Ministry of Mines and Energy, the National Council for Energy Policy, the <a href="/wiki/National_Agency_of_Petroleum,_Natural_Gas_and_Biofuels_(Brazil)" title="National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels (Brazil)">National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Electricity_Regulatory_Agency" title="Brazilian Electricity Regulatory Agency">National Agency of Electricity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD2005_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD2005-378">[373]</a></sup> In the beginning of 2020, in the production of <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>, the country exceeded 4 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, for the first time. In January this year, 3.168 million barrels of oil per day and 138.753 million cubic meters of natural gas were extracted.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[374]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Brazil" title="Tourism in Brazil">Tourism in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg/220px-Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg/330px-Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg/440px-Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Sancho Bay in <a href="/wiki/Fernando_de_Noronha" title="Fernando de Noronha">Fernando de Noronha Archipelago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pernambuco" title="Pernambuco">Pernambuco</a>, voted the most beautiful beach in the world by <a href="/wiki/TripAdvisor" class="mw-redirect" title="TripAdvisor">TripAdvisor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-praias_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-praias-380">[375]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Abismo_Anhumas,_Bonito,_MS.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG/220px-Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG/330px-Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG/440px-Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Bonito,_Mato_Grosso_do_Sul" title="Bonito, Mato Grosso do Sul">Bonito</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso_do_Sul" title="Mato Grosso do Sul">Mato Grosso do Sul</a>. The rivers in the region are known for their crystal clear waters.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Tourism in Brazil is a growing sector and key to the economy of several regions of the country. The country had 6.36&nbsp;million visitors in 2015, ranking in terms of the international tourist arrivals as the main destination in South America and second in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> after Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[376]</a></sup> Revenues from international tourists reached <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$6</span> billion in 2010, showing a recovery from the <a href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" class="mw-redirect" title="Late-2000s recession">2008–2009 economic crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-UNWTO2011_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO2011-382">[377]</a></sup> Historical records of 5.4&nbsp;million visitors and <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$6.8</span> billion in receipts were reached in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-MT1_2011_383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MT1_2011-383">[378]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MT2_2011_384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MT2_2011-384">[379]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Natural areas are its most popular tourism product, a combination of <a href="/wiki/Ecotourism" title="Ecotourism">ecotourism</a> with leisure and recreation, mainly sun and beach, and adventure travel, as well as cultural tourism. Among the most popular destinations are the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Rainforest" class="mw-redirect" title="Amazon Rainforest">Amazon Rainforest</a>, beaches and dunes in the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Northeast Region, Brazil">Northeast Region</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pantanal" title="Pantanal">Pantanal</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Center-West_Region,_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Center-West Region, Brazil">Center-West Region</a>, beaches at <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">Rio de Janeiro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state)" title="Santa Catarina (state)">Santa Catarina</a>, cultural tourism in <a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a> and business trips to <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Palhares2012_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Palhares2012-385">[380]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In terms of the 2015 <a href="/wiki/Travel_and_Tourism_Competitiveness_Report" title="Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report">Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Index</a> (TTCI), which is a measurement of the factors that make it attractive to develop business in the travel and tourism industry of individual countries, Brazil ranked in the 28st place at the world's level, third in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, after Canada and United States.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[381]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TTCI2013_387-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TTCI2013-387">[382]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil's main competitive advantages are its natural resources, which ranked 1st on this criteria out of all countries considered, and ranked 23rd for its cultural resources, due to its many <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_site" class="mw-redirect" title="World Heritage site">World Heritage sites</a>. The TTCI report notes Brazil's main weaknesses: its ground transport infrastructure remains underdeveloped (ranked 116th), with the quality of roads ranking in 105th place; and the country continues to suffer from a lack of price competitiveness (ranked 114th), due in part to high ticket taxes and airport charges, as well as high prices and high taxation. Safety and security have improved significantly: 75th in 2011, up from 128th in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-TTCI2013_387-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TTCI2013-387">[382]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization" title="World Tourism Organization">World Tourism Organization</a> (WTO), international travel to Brazil accelerated in 2000, particularly during 2004 and 2005. However, in 2006 a slow-down took place, and international arrivals had almost no growth in 2007–08.<sup id="cite_ref-WTO2007_388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTO2007-388">[383]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EMBRATUR09_389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EMBRATUR09-389">[384]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[385]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In spite of this trend, revenues from international tourism continued to rise, from <a href="/wiki/USD" class="mw-redirect" title="USD">USD</a> 4&nbsp;billion in 2005 to 5&nbsp;billion in 2007, despite 330 000 fewer arrivals. This favorable trend is the result of the strong devaluation of the US dollar against the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Real" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian Real">Brazilian Real</a>, which began in 2004, but which makes Brazil a more expensive international destination.<sup id="cite_ref-Boletim0207_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0207-391">[386]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg/220px-Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg/330px-Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg/440px-Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5357" data-file-height="3571"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The city of <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> is featured in <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Brazil" title="Tourism in Brazil">tourism in Brazil</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Cataratas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cataratas.jpg/220px-Cataratas.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cataratas.jpg/330px-Cataratas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cataratas.jpg/440px-Cataratas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3961" data-file-height="2644"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Iguazu_Falls" title="Iguazu Falls">Iguazu Falls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_(state)" title="Paraná (state)">Paraná</a>, at the <a href="/wiki/Argentina%E2%80%93Brazil_relations" title="Argentina–Brazil relations">Brazil-Argentina border</a>. The Garganta do Diabo Walkway allows a panoramic view of the falls from the Brazilian side.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>This trend changed in 2009, when both visitors and revenues fell as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a> of 2008–09.<sup id="cite_ref-WTO2010_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTO2010-392">[387]</a></sup> By 2010, the industry had recovered, and arrivals grew above 2006 levels to 5.2&nbsp;million international visitors, and receipts from these visitors reached US$6&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-UNWTO2011_382-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO2011-382">[377]</a></sup> In 2011 the historical record was reached with 5.4&nbsp;million visitors and <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$6.8</span> billion in receipts.<sup id="cite_ref-MT1_2011_383-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MT1_2011-383">[378]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MT2_2011_384-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MT2_2011-384">[379]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Despite continuing record-breaking international tourism revenues, the number of Brazilian tourists travelling overseas has been growing steadily since 2003, resulting in a net negative <a href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_market" title="Foreign exchange market">foreign exchange</a> balance, as more money is spent abroad by Brazilians than comes in as receipts from international tourists visiting Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-Boletim0308_393-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0308-393">[388]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Tourism expenditures abroad grew from US$5.8&nbsp;billion in 2006, to US$8.2&nbsp;billion in 2007, a 42% increase, representing a net deficit of US$3.3&nbsp;billion in 2007, as compared to US$1.5&nbsp;billion in 2006, a 125% increase from the previous year.<sup id="cite_ref-Boletim0308_393-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0308-393">[388]</a></sup> This trend is caused by Brazilians taking advantage of the stronger <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_real" title="Brazilian real">Real</a> to travel and making relatively cheaper expenditures abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-Boletim0308_393-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0308-393">[388]</a></sup> Brazilians traveling overseas in 2006 represented 4% of the country's population.<sup id="cite_ref-FIPE006_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIPE006-394">[389]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2005, tourism contributed with 3.2% of the country's revenues from exports of goods and services, and represented 7% of direct and indirect employment in the Brazilian economy.<sup id="cite_ref-BID2006_395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BID2006-395">[390]</a></sup> In 2006 direct employment in the sector reached 1.9&nbsp;million people.<sup id="cite_ref-IPEA08_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IPEA08-396">[391]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Domestic tourism is a fundamental market segment for the industry, as 51 million people traveled throughout the country in 2005,<sup id="cite_ref-FIPE007_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIPE007-397">[392]</a></sup> and direct revenues from Brazilian tourists reached US$22&nbsp;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[393]</a></sup> 5.6 times more receipts than international tourists in 2005. </p>
      <p>In 2005, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Foz_do_Igua%C3%A7u" title="Foz do Iguaçu">Foz do Iguaçu</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Florian%C3%B3polis" title="Florianópolis">Florianópolis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia" title="Salvador, Bahia">Salvador</a> were the most visited cities by international tourists for leisure trips. The most popular destinations for business trips were São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and <a href="/wiki/Porto_Alegre" title="Porto Alegre">Porto Alegre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EMBRATUR06_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EMBRATUR06-399">[394]</a></sup> In 2006 Rio de Janeiro and <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a> were the most popular destinations for business trips. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Brazil" title="Science and technology in Brazil">Science and technology in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Vls1-mockup-test.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Vls1-mockup-test.jpg/220px-Vls1-mockup-test.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Vls1-mockup-test.jpg/330px-Vls1-mockup-test.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Vls1-mockup-test.jpg/440px-Vls1-mockup-test.jpg 2x" data-file-width="620" data-file-height="413"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/VLS-1" title="VLS-1">VLS-1</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Alc%C3%A2ntara_Launch_Center" title="Alcântara Launch Center">Alcântara Launch Center</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Space_Agency" title="Brazilian Space Agency">Brazilian Space Agency</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._(45909188621).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg/220px-Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg/330px-Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg/440px-Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5760" data-file-height="3840"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Sirius_(synchrotron_light_source)" title="Sirius (synchrotron light source)">Sirius</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Diffraction-limited_storage_ring" title="Diffraction-limited storage ring">diffraction-limited storage ring</a> <a href="/wiki/Synchrotron_radiation" title="Synchrotron radiation">synchrotron light source</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Laborat%C3%B3rio_Nacional_de_Luz_S%C3%ADncrotron" title="Laboratório Nacional de Luz Síncrotron">Laboratório Nacional de Luz Síncrotron</a>, in the municipality of <a href="/wiki/Campinas" title="Campinas">Campinas</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="São Paulo (state)">São Paulo</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Technological research in Brazil is largely carried out in public universities and research institutes, with the majority of funding for basic research coming from various government agencies.<sup id="cite_ref-DevelopmentStaff2006v_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DevelopmentStaff2006v-400">[395]</a></sup> Brazil's most esteemed technological hubs are the <a href="/wiki/Funda%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Oswaldo_Cruz" class="mw-redirect" title="Fundação Oswaldo Cruz">Oswaldo Cruz Institute</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Butantan" title="Instituto Butantan">Butantan Institute</a>, the Air Force's <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_General_Command_for_Aerospace_Technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian General Command for Aerospace Technology">Aerospace Technical Center</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Empresa_Brasileira_de_Pesquisa_Agropecu%C3%A1ria" class="mw-redirect" title="Empresa Brasileira de Pesquisa Agropecuária">Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_for_Space_Research" title="National Institute for Space Research">National Institute for Space Research</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Scientific2010f_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scientific2010f-401">[396]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-HarveySmid2010_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HarveySmid2010-402">[397]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Space_Agency" title="Brazilian Space Agency">Brazilian Space Agency</a> has the most advanced space program in Latin America, with significant resources to launch vehicles, and manufacture of <a href="/wiki/Artificial_satellite" class="mw-redirect" title="Artificial satellite">satellites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidvP9jHaoL_s4CpgPA628_628]_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidvP9jHaoL_s4CpgPA628_628]-403">[398]</a></sup> Owner of relative technological sophistication, the country develops <a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarines</a>, aircraft, as well as being involved in space research, having a Vehicle Launch Center Light and being the only country in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a> the integrate team building <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a> (ISS).<sup id="cite_ref-NASA_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NASA-404">[399]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The country is also a pioneer in the search for oil in deep water, from where it extracts 73% of its reserves. <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">Uranium</a> is enriched at the <a href="/wiki/Resende_Nuclear_Fuel_Factory" title="Resende Nuclear Fuel Factory">Resende Nuclear Fuel Factory</a>, mostly for research purposes (as Brazil obtains 88% from its electricity from <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectricity</a><sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[400]</a></sup>) and the country's first nuclear submarine was delivered in 2015 (by France).<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[401]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil is one of the three countries in Latin America<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[402]</a></sup> with an operational <a href="/wiki/Synchrotron" title="Synchrotron">Synchrotron</a> Laboratory, a research facility on physics, chemistry, material science and life sciences, and Brazil is the only Latin American country to have a <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor" title="Semiconductor">semiconductor</a> company with its own <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor_fabrication_plant" title="Semiconductor fabrication plant">fabrication plant</a>, the <a href="/wiki/CEITEC" title="CEITEC">CEITEC</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[403]</a></sup> According to the Global Information Technology Report 2009-2010 of the World Economic Forum, Brazil is the world's 61st largest developer of information technology.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[404]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Among the most renowned Brazilian inventors are priests <a href="/wiki/Bartolomeu_de_Gusm%C3%A3o" title="Bartolomeu de Gusmão">Bartolomeu de Gusmão</a>, <a href="/wiki/Landell_de_Moura" class="mw-redirect" title="Landell de Moura">Landell de Moura</a> and Francisco João de Azevedo, besides <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Santos-Dumont" title="Alberto Santos-Dumont">Alberto Santos-Dumont</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[405]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Evaristo_Conrado_Engelberg" title="Evaristo Conrado Engelberg">Evaristo Conrado Engelberg</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-patentbritish_411-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-patentbritish-411">[406]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Dias_de_Abreu" class="mw-redirect" title="Manuel Dias de Abreu">Manuel Dias de Abreu</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[407]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Andreas_Pavel" title="Andreas Pavel">Andreas Pavel</a><sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[408]</a></sup> and Nélio José Nicolai.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[409]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazilian science is represented by the likes of <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Lattes" title="César Lattes">César Lattes</a> (Brazilian <a href="/wiki/Physicist" title="Physicist">physicist</a> Pathfinder of <i><a href="/wiki/Pion" title="Pion">Pi Meson</a></i>),<sup id="cite_ref-Lattes_415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lattes-415">[410]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1rio_Schenberg" title="Mário Schenberg">Mário Schenberg</a> (considered the greatest theoretical physicist of Brazil),<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[411]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Leite_Lopes" title="José Leite Lopes">José Leite Lopes</a> (only Brazilian physicist holder of the <i>UNESCO Science Prize</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[412]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Artur_%C3%81vila" class="mw-redirect" title="Artur Ávila">Artur Ávila</a> (the first Latin American winner of the <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[413]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Fritz_M%C3%BCller" title="Fritz Müller">Fritz Müller</a> (pioneer in factual support of the theory of evolution by Charles Darwin).<sup id="cite_ref-West,_David_A_2003_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-West,_David_A_2003-419">[414]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Brazil" title="Transport in Brazil">Transport in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Rodovias_Duplicadas_do_Brasil,_Junho_de_2019.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Rodovias_Duplicadas_do_Brasil%2C_Junho_de_2019.jpg/200px-Rodovias_Duplicadas_do_Brasil%2C_Junho_de_2019.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="193" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Rodovias_Duplicadas_do_Brasil%2C_Junho_de_2019.jpg/300px-Rodovias_Duplicadas_do_Brasil%2C_Junho_de_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Rodovias_Duplicadas_do_Brasil%2C_Junho_de_2019.jpg/400px-Rodovias_Duplicadas_do_Brasil%2C_Junho_de_2019.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3254" data-file-height="3142"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Rodovias_Duplicadas_do_Brasil,_Junho_de_2019.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>
         <center>
          Road system in Brazil, with <a href="/wiki/Dual_carriageway" title="Dual carriageway">divided highways</a> highlighted in red.
         </center>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mapa_portos.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Mapa_portos.jpg/220px-Mapa_portos.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="198" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Mapa_portos.jpg/330px-Mapa_portos.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Mapa_portos.jpg/440px-Mapa_portos.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="719"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mapa_portos.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Main ports in Brazil
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Brazilian roads are the primary carriers of freight and passenger traffic. The road system totaled 1.98&nbsp;million km (1.23&nbsp;million mi) in 2002. The total of paved roads increased from 35,496&nbsp;km (22,056&nbsp;mi) in 1967 to 215,000&nbsp;km (133,595&nbsp;mi) in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[415]</a></sup> <sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[416]</a></sup> The country has about 14,000&nbsp;km (8,699&nbsp;mi) of <a href="/wiki/Divided_highways" class="mw-redirect" title="Divided highways">divided highways</a>, 5,000&nbsp;km (3,107&nbsp;mi) only in the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="São Paulo (state)">State of São Paulo</a>. Currently it's possible to travel from <a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande,_Rio_Grande_do_Sul" title="Rio Grande, Rio Grande do Sul">Rio Grande</a>, in the extreme south of the country, to <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Brasília">Brasília</a> (2,580&nbsp;km (1,603&nbsp;mi)) or <a href="/wiki/Casimiro_de_Abreu,_Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Casimiro de Abreu, Rio de Janeiro">Casimiro de Abreu</a>, in the state of <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">Rio de Janeiro</a> (2,045&nbsp;km (1,271&nbsp;mi)), only on divided highways. </p>
      <p>The first investments in road infrastructure have given up in the 1920s, the government of <a href="/wiki/Washington_Lu%C3%ADs" title="Washington Luís">Washington Luís</a>, being pursued in the governments of <a href="/wiki/Get%C3%BAlio_Vargas" title="Getúlio Vargas">Getúlio Vargas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eurico_Gaspar_Dutra" title="Eurico Gaspar Dutra">Eurico Gaspar Dutra</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[417]</a></sup> President <a href="/wiki/Juscelino_Kubitschek" title="Juscelino Kubitschek">Juscelino Kubitschek</a> (1956–61), who designed and built the capital Brasília, was another supporter of highways. Kubitschek was responsible for the installation of major car manufacturers in the country (<a href="/wiki/Volkswagen" title="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company" title="Ford Motor Company">Ford</a> and <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a> arrived in Brazil during his rule) and one of the points used to attract them was support for the construction of highways. With the implementation of <a href="/wiki/Fiat" title="Fiat">Fiat</a> in 1976 ending an automobile market closed loop, from the end of the 1990s the country has received large foreign direct investments installing in its territory other major car manufacturers and utilities, such as <a href="/wiki/Iveco" title="Iveco">Iveco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renault" title="Renault">Renault</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn" title="Citroën">Citroën</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honda" title="Honda">Honda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mitsubishi" title="Mitsubishi">Mitsubishi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a>, <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hyundai_Motor_Company" title="Hyundai Motor Company">Hyundai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">Toyota</a> among others.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[418]</a></sup> Brazil is the seventh most important country in the <a href="/wiki/Auto_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Auto industry">auto industry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[419]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil's <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport" title="Rail transport">railway</a> system has been declining since 1945, when emphasis shifted to highway construction. The total length of railway track was 30,875&nbsp;km (19,185&nbsp;mi) in 2002, as compared with 31,848&nbsp;km (19,789&nbsp;mi) in 1970. Most of the railway system belonged to the Federal Railroad Corporation RFFSA, which was privatized in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[420]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_Metro" title="São Paulo Metro">São Paulo Metro</a> was the first underground transit system in Brazil. The other metro systems are in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto_Alegre" title="Porto Alegre">Porto Alegre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Recife" title="Recife">Recife</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a>, Brasília, <a href="/wiki/Teresina" title="Teresina">Teresina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a>. </p>
      <p>The country has an extensive rail network of 28,538 kilometres (17,733 miles) in length, the tenth largest network in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-2012ciagini_426-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012ciagini-426">[421]</a></sup> Currently, the Brazilian government, unlike the past, seeks to encourage this mode of transport; an example of this incentive is the project of the <a href="/wiki/Rio%E2%80%93S%C3%A3o_Paulo_high-speed_rail" title="Rio–São Paulo high-speed rail">Rio–São Paulo high-speed rail</a>, that will connect the two main cities of the country to carry passengers. </p>
      <p>There are about 2,500 airports in Brazil, including landing fields: the second largest number in the world, after the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[422]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo%E2%80%93Guarulhos_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="São Paulo–Guarulhos International Airport">São Paulo–Guarulhos International Airport</a>, near São Paulo, is the largest and busiest airport with nearly 20 million passengers annually, while handling the vast majority of commercial traffic for the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Palhares2012x_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Palhares2012x-428">[423]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>For freight transport <a href="/wiki/Waterways" class="mw-redirect" title="Waterways">waterways</a> are of importance, e.g. the <a href="/wiki/Free_Economic_Zone_of_Manaus" title="Free Economic Zone of Manaus">industrial zones of Manaus</a> can be reached only by means of the Solimões–Amazonas waterway (3,250 kilometres (2,020 miles) with 6 metres (20 feet) minimum depth). The country also has 50,000 kilometres (31,000 miles) of waterways.<sup id="cite_ref-2012ciagini_426-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012ciagini-426">[421]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Coastal shipping links widely separated parts of the country. Bolivia and Paraguay have been given free ports at <a href="/wiki/Santos,_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Santos, São Paulo">Santos</a>. Of the 36 deep-water ports, Santos, Itajaí, Rio Grande, Paranaguá, Rio de Janeiro, Sepetiba, Vitória, Suape, Manaus and São Francisco do Sul are the most important.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[424]</a></sup> Bulk carriers have to wait up to 18 days before being serviced, container ships 36.3 hours on average.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[425]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="Ambox current red Americas.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png" decoding="async" width="42" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="290">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">February 2021</span>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Brazil" title="Health in Brazil">Health in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Fotorreportagem_do_ICESP_(42627443635).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Fotorreportagem_do_ICESP_%2842627443635%29.jpg/220px-Fotorreportagem_do_ICESP_%2842627443635%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Fotorreportagem_do_ICESP_%2842627443635%29.jpg/330px-Fotorreportagem_do_ICESP_%2842627443635%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Fotorreportagem_do_ICESP_%2842627443635%29.jpg/440px-Fotorreportagem_do_ICESP_%2842627443635%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="2750"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Fotorreportagem_do_ICESP_(42627443635).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Cancer_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Institute of Cancer of São Paulo">Institute of Cancer</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Hospital_das_Cl%C3%ADnicas_da_Universidade_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Hospital das Clínicas da Universidade de São Paulo">University of São Paulo Clinics Hospital</a>, the largest <a href="/wiki/Academic_health_science_centre" title="Academic health science centre">hospital complex</a> in Latin America.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[426]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Brazilian <a href="/wiki/Public_health" title="Public health">public health</a> system, the <a href="/wiki/Sistema_%C3%9Anico_de_Sa%C3%BAde" title="Sistema Único de Saúde">Unified Health System</a> (SUS), is managed and provided by all levels of government,<sup id="cite_ref-ForgiaCouttolenc2008_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ForgiaCouttolenc2008-432">[427]</a></sup> being the largest system of this type in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[428]</a></sup> On the other hand, private healthcare systems play a complementary role.<sup id="cite_ref-Wolper2004_434-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wolper2004-434">[429]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Public health services are universal and offered to all citizens of the country for free. However, the construction and maintenance of health centers and hospitals are financed by taxes, and the country spends about 9% of its GDP on expenditures in the area. In 2012, Brazil had 1.85 doctors and 2.3 hospital beds for every 1,000 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[430]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[431]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Despite all the progress made since the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> system in 1988, there are still several public health problems in Brazil. In 2006, the main points to be solved were the high <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_infant_mortality_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by infant mortality rate">infant</a> (2.51%) and maternal mortality rates (73.1 deaths per 1000 births).<sup id="cite_ref-Radar_social_437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Radar_social-437">[432]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The number of deaths from noncommunicable diseases, such as <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardiovascular diseases">cardiovascular diseases</a> (151.7 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants) and <a href="/wiki/Cancer" title="Cancer">cancer</a> (72.7 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants), also has a considerable impact on the health of the Brazilian population. Finally, external but preventable factors such as car accidents, violence and suicide caused 14.9% of all deaths in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Radar_social_437-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Radar_social-437">[432]</a></sup> The Brazilian health system was ranked 125th among the 191 countries evaluated by the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO) in 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[433]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Brazil" title="Education in Brazil">Education in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg/220px-Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg/330px-Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg/440px-Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2288" data-file-height="1712"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Historical building of the <a href="/wiki/Federal_University_of_Paran%C3%A1" title="Federal University of Paraná">Federal University of Paraná</a>, one of the oldest universities in Brazil, located in <a href="/wiki/Curitiba" title="Curitiba">Curitiba</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg/220px-Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg/330px-Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg/440px-Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Classroom in the main campus of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Campinas" title="University of Campinas">University of Campinas</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="São Paulo (state)">São Paulo</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">Federal Constitution</a> and the Law of Guidelines and Bases of National Education determine that the <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_Brazil" title="Federal government of Brazil">Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">states</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_District_(Brazil)" title="Federal District (Brazil)">Federal District</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Brazil" title="Municipalities of Brazil">municipalities</a> must manage and organize their respective education systems. Each of these public educational systems is responsible for its own maintenance, which manages funds as well as the mechanisms and funding sources. The constitution reserves 25% of the state budget and 18% of federal taxes and municipal taxes for education.<sup id="cite_ref-Usa2005_439-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Usa2005-439">[434]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Institute_of_Geography_and_Statistics" title="Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics">IBGE</a>, in 2011, the literacy rate of the population was 90.4%, meaning that 13 million (9.6% of population) people are still illiterate in the country; functional illiteracy has reached 21.6% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-Agency2010_440-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agency2010-440">[435]</a></sup> Illiteracy is highest in the Northeast, where 19.9% of the population is illiterate.<sup id="cite_ref-Bank2001_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bank2001-441">[436]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Higher education starts with undergraduate or sequential <a href="/wiki/Course_(education)" title="Course (education)">courses</a>, which may offer different options of specialization in academic or <a href="/wiki/Professional" title="Professional">professional</a> careers. Depending on the choice, students can improve their educational background with courses of post-graduate studies or broad sense. </p>
      <p>Attending an institution of higher education is required by Law of Guidelines and Bases of Education. <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">Kindergarten</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elementary_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Elementary school">elementary</a> and medium education are required of all students, provided the student does not hold any disability, whether physical, <a href="/wiki/Mind" title="Mind">mental</a>, <a href="/wiki/Visual" class="mw-redirect" title="Visual">visual</a> or <a href="/wiki/Hearing_(sense)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hearing (sense)">hearing</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/University_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="University of São Paulo">University of São Paulo</a> is the second best <a href="/wiki/University" title="University">university</a> in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, according to recent 2019 <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a>. Of the top 20 Latin American universities, eight are Brazilian. Most of them are <a href="/wiki/Public_university" title="Public university">public</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[437]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Brazil</a>'s private institutions tend to be more exclusive and offer better quality education, so many high-income families send their children there. The result is a segregated educational system that reflects extreme income disparities and reinforces social inequality. However, efforts to change this are making impacts.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[438]</a></sup> </p>
