      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_communication">Media and communication<span class="anchor" id="Media"></span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Brazil" title="Telecommunications in Brazil">Telecommunications in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Brazil" title="Television in Brazil">Television in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Concentration_of_media_ownership#Brazil" title="Concentration of media ownership">Concentration of media ownership §&nbsp;Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg/220px-Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg/330px-Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg/440px-Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="683"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Former President <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a> at <i><a href="/wiki/Jornal_Nacional" title="Jornal Nacional">Jornal Nacional</a></i> news program. <a href="/wiki/Rede_Globo" title="Rede Globo">Rede Globo</a> is the world's second-largest commercial television network.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[439]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Brazilian press was officially born in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> on 13 May 1808 with the creation of the Royal Printing National Press by the <a href="/wiki/Prince_Regent" class="mw-redirect" title="Prince Regent">Prince Regent</a> <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_VI_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="João VI of Portugal">Dom João</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EchevarríaPupo-Walker1996_445-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EchevarríaPupo-Walker1996-445">[440]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <i>Gazeta do Rio de Janeiro</i>, the first newspaper published in the country, began to circulate on 10 September 1808.<sup id="cite_ref-Johnston2003_446-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnston2003-446">[441]</a></sup> The largest newspapers nowadays are <i><a href="/wiki/Folha_de_S.Paulo" title="Folha de S.Paulo">Folha de S.Paulo</a>,</i> <i>Super Notícia</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/O_Globo" title="O Globo">O Globo</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/O_Estado_de_S._Paulo" title="O Estado de S. Paulo">O Estado de S. Paulo</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Vincent2003B_447-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vincent2003B-447">[442]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Radio broadcasting began on 7 September 1922, with a speech by then President Pessoa, and was formalized on 20 April 1923 with the creation of "Radio Society of Rio de Janeiro."<sup id="cite_ref-McCann2004_448-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCann2004-448">[443]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Television in Brazil began officially on 18 September 1950, with the founding of <a href="/wiki/TV_Tupi" class="mw-redirect" title="TV Tupi">TV Tupi</a> by <a href="/wiki/Assis_Chateaubriand" title="Assis Chateaubriand">Assis Chateaubriand</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ward2007_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ward2007-449">[444]</a></sup> Since then television has grown in the country, creating large commercial broadcast networks such as <a href="/wiki/Rede_Globo" title="Rede Globo">Globo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sistema_Brasileiro_de_Televis%C3%A3o" title="Sistema Brasileiro de Televisão">SBT</a>, <a href="/wiki/RecordTV" title="RecordTV">RecordTV</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rede_Bandeirantes" title="Rede Bandeirantes">Bandeirantes</a> and <a href="/wiki/RedeTV!" title="RedeTV!">RedeTV</a>. Today it is the most important factor in popular culture of Brazilian society, indicated by research showing that as much as 67%<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[445]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[446]</a></sup> of the general population follow the same daily <a href="/wiki/Soap_opera" title="Soap opera">soap opera</a> broadcast. Digital Television, using the <a href="/wiki/SBTVD" class="mw-redirect" title="SBTVD">SBTVD</a> standard (based on the Japanese standard <a href="/wiki/ISDB-T" class="mw-redirect" title="ISDB-T">ISDB-T</a>), was adopted on 29 June 2006 and launched on 2 November 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-Alencar2009_452-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alencar2009-452">[447]</a></sup> In May 2010, the Brazilian government launched <a href="/wiki/TV_Brasil_Internacional" title="TV Brasil Internacional">TV Brasil Internacional</a>, an international <a href="/wiki/Television_station" title="Television station">television station</a>, initially broadcasting to 49 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[448]</a></sup> Commercial television channels broadcast internationally include <a href="/wiki/Globo_Internacional" title="Globo Internacional">Globo Internacional</a>, <a href="/wiki/RecordTV_Internacional" title="RecordTV Internacional">RecordTV Internacional</a> and <a href="/wiki/Band_Internacional" title="Band Internacional">Band Internacional</a>. </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Brazil" title="Demographics of Brazil">Demographics of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazilians" title="Brazilians">Brazilians</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Brazil" title="Immigration to Brazil">Immigration to Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Brazilian_states_by_population_density" title="List of Brazilian states by population density">List of Brazilian states by population density</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png/300px-ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="305" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png/450px-ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2e/ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png 2x" data-file-width="593" data-file-height="603"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Population density of Brazilian municipalities
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The population of Brazil, as recorded by the 2008 PNAD, was approximately 190 million<sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[449]</a></sup> (22.31 inhabitants per square kilometre or 57.8/sq&nbsp;mi), with a ratio of men to women of 0.95:1<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[450]</a></sup> and 83.75% of the population defined as urban.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[451]</a></sup> The population is heavily concentrated in the Southeastern (79.8&nbsp;million inhabitants) and Northeastern (53.5&nbsp;million inhabitants) regions, while the two most extensive regions, the Center-West and the North, which together make up 64.12% of the Brazilian territory, have a total of only 29.1&nbsp;million inhabitants. </p>
      <p>The first census in Brazil was carried out in 1872 and recorded a population of 9,930,478.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[452]</a></sup> From 1880 to 1930, 4 million Europeans arrived.<sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458">[453]</a></sup> Brazil's population increased significantly between 1940 and 1970, because of a decline in the <a href="/wiki/Mortality_rate" title="Mortality rate">mortality rate</a>, even though the <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a> underwent a slight decline. In the 1940s the annual <a href="/wiki/Population_growth" title="Population growth">population growth rate</a> was 2.4%, rising to 3.0% in the 1950s and remaining at 2.9% in the 1960s, as life expectancy rose from 44 to 54 years<sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[454]</a></sup> and to 72.6 years in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[455]</a></sup> It has been steadily falling since the 1960s, from 3.04% per year between 1950 and 1960 to 1.05% in 2008 and is expected to fall to a negative value of&nbsp;–0.29% by 2050<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">[456]</a></sup> thus completing the <a href="/wiki/Demographic_transition" title="Demographic transition">demographic transition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">[457]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2008, the illiteracy rate was 11.48%<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[458]</a></sup> and among the <a href="/wiki/Youth_in_Brazil" title="Youth in Brazil">youth</a> (ages 15–19) 1.74%. It was highest (20.30%) in the Northeast, which had a large proportion of rural poor.<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[459]</a></sup> Illiteracy was high (24.18%) among the rural population and lower (9.05%) among the urban population.<sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465">[460]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Race_and_ethnicity">Race and ethnicity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_Brazil" title="Race and ethnicity in Brazil">Race and ethnicity in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG/220px-Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG/330px-Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG/440px-Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Immigration_Museum_of_the_State_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Immigration Museum of the State of São Paulo">Immigration Museum of the State of São Paulo</a> in the neighborhood of <a href="/wiki/Mooca_(district_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo)" title="Mooca (district of São Paulo)">Mooca</a>, in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_city" class="mw-redirect" title="São Paulo city">São Paulo city</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Brazilians" title="Italian Brazilians">Italian Brazilians</a> are 15% of the population and the largest Italian community outside <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[461]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px"> 
        <div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black"> 
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 15915.284869129px; border-left-color:Red"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Red"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Red"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 3182.0515953774px; border-left-color:#FFE135"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#FFE135"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#FFE135"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 991.36510217697px; border-left-color:MediumAquamarine"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:MediumAquamarine"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:MediumAquamarine"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 153.28270598844px; border-left-color:#9966CC"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#9966CC"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#9966CC"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:0; border-width:0 687.15418461364px 100px 0; border-right-color:LightBlue"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;right:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 100px 0;border-color:LightBlue"></div> 
        </div> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <p><a href="/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_Brazil" title="Race and ethnicity in Brazil">Race and ethnicity in Brazil</a><sup id="cite_ref-IBGE_Censo_de_2000_467-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IBGE_Censo_de_2000-467">[462]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Etnias_Censo_2010_468-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Etnias_Censo_2010-468">[463]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[464]</a></sup> </p> 
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:LightBlue; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/White_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="White Brazilian">White</a> (47.7%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#9966CC; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Pardo_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Pardo Brazilian">Pardo</a> (<a href="/wiki/Multiracial#Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Multiracial">Multiracial</a>) (43.1%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:MediumAquamarine; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Black_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Black Brazilian">Black</a> (7.6%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#FFE135; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Asian_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Asian Brazilian">Asian</a> (1.1%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Red; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Brazil" title="Indigenous peoples in Brazil">Natives</a> (0.4%)
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Institute_of_Geography_and_Statistics" title="Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics">National Research by Household Sample</a> (PNAD) of 2008, 48.43% of the population (about 92 million) described themselves as <a href="/wiki/White_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="White Brazilian">White</a>; 43.80% (about 83 million) as <a href="/wiki/Pardo_Brazilians" title="Pardo Brazilians">Pardo</a> (<a href="/wiki/Brown_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Brown people">brown</a>), 6.84% (about 13 million) as <a href="/wiki/Black_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Black Brazilian">Black</a>; 0.58% (about 1.1&nbsp;million) as <a href="/wiki/Asian_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Asian Brazilian">Asian</a>; and 0.28% (about 536 thousand) as <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Brazil" title="Indigenous peoples in Brazil">Amerindian</a> (officially called <i>indígena</i>, Indigenous), while 0.07% (about 130 thousand) did not declare their race.<sup id="cite_ref-PNADIBGE_470-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PNADIBGE-470">[465]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2007, the <a href="/wiki/Funda%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Nacional_do_%C3%8Dndio" title="Fundação Nacional do Índio">National Indian Foundation</a> estimated that Brazil has 67 different uncontacted tribes, up from their estimate of 40 in 2005. Brazil is believed to have the largest number of <a href="/wiki/Uncontacted_peoples" title="Uncontacted peoples">uncontacted peoples</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[466]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since the arrival of the Portuguese in 1500, considerable genetic mixing between Amerindians, Europeans, and Africans has taken place in all regions of the country (with European ancestry being dominant nationwide according to the vast majority of all autosomal studies undertaken covering the entire population, accounting for between 65% to 77%).<sup id="cite_ref-alvaro.com.br_472-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alvaro.com.br-472">[467]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-www1.folha.uol.com.br_473-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www1.folha.uol.com.br-473">[468]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bdtd.bce.unb.br_474-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bdtd.bce.unb.br-474">[469]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-plosone.org_475-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-plosone.org-475">[470]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazilian society is more <a href="/wiki/Social_issues_in_Brazil" title="Social issues in Brazil">markedly divided by social class lines</a>, although a high <a href="/wiki/Income_inequality_in_Brazil" title="Income inequality in Brazil">income disparity</a> is found <a href="/wiki/Social_apartheid_in_Brazil" title="Social apartheid in Brazil">between race groups</a>, so <a href="/wiki/Racism" title="Racism">racism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Class_discrimination" title="Class discrimination">classism</a> can be conflated. Socially significant closeness to one racial group <a href="/wiki/Race_in_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Race in Brazil">is taken in account</a> more in the basis of appearance (<a href="/wiki/Phenotype" title="Phenotype">phenotypes</a>) rather than ancestry, to the extent that full <a href="/wiki/Sibling" title="Sibling">siblings</a> can pertain to different "racial" groups.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[471]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Socioeconomic_status" title="Socioeconomic status">Socioeconomic</a> factors are also significant, because a minority of <a href="/wiki/Pardo_Brazilians" title="Pardo Brazilians"><i>pardos</i></a> are likely to start declaring themselves White or Black if socially upward.<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[472]</a></sup> Skin color and facial features do not line quite well with ancestry (usually, Afro-Brazilians are evenly mixed and European ancestry is dominant in Whites and <i>pardos</i> with a significant non-European contribution, but the individual variation is great).<sup id="cite_ref-plosone.org_475-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-plosone.org-475">[470]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-afrobras_478-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-afrobras-478">[473]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">[474]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480">[475]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The brown population (officially called <a href="/wiki/Pardo_Brazilians" title="Pardo Brazilians"><i>pardo</i></a> in Portuguese, also colloquially <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/moreno" class="extiw" title="wikt:moreno">moreno</a></i>)<sup id="cite_ref-Coelho_1996,_p.&nbsp;268_481-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coelho_1996,_p._268-481">[476]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vesentini_1988,_p.&nbsp;117_482-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vesentini_1988,_p._117-482">[477]</a></sup> is a broad category that includes <i><a href="/wiki/Caboclo" title="Caboclo">caboclos</a></i> (assimilated Amerindians in general, and descendants of Whites and Natives), <i><a href="/wiki/Mulatto" title="Mulatto">mulatos</a></i> (descendants of primarily Whites and Afro-Brazilians) and <i><a href="/wiki/Zambo" title="Zambo">cafuzos</a></i> (descendants of Afro-Brazilians and Natives).<sup id="cite_ref-Coelho_1996,_p.&nbsp;268_481-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coelho_1996,_p._268-481">[476]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vesentini_1988,_p.&nbsp;117_482-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vesentini_1988,_p._117-482">[477]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483">[478]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484">[479]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Moreira_1981,_p.&nbsp;108_485-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moreira_1981,_p._108-485">[480]</a></sup> People of considerable Amerindian ancestry form the majority of the population in the Northern, Northeastern and Center-Western regions.<sup id="cite_ref-486" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-486">[481]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Higher percents of Blacks, mulattoes and tri-racials can be found in the eastern coast of the Northeastern region from Bahia to Paraíba<sup id="cite_ref-Moreira_1981,_p.&nbsp;108_485-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moreira_1981,_p._108-485">[480]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487">[482]</a></sup> and also in northern Maranhão,<sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488">[483]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-489" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489">[484]</a></sup> southern Minas Gerais<sup id="cite_ref-Azevedo_1971,_p.&nbsp;161_490-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Azevedo_1971,_p._161-490">[485]</a></sup> and in eastern Rio de Janeiro.<sup id="cite_ref-Moreira_1981,_p.&nbsp;108_485-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moreira_1981,_p._108-485">[480]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Azevedo_1971,_p.&nbsp;161_490-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Azevedo_1971,_p._161-490">[485]</a></sup> From the 19th century, Brazil opened its borders to <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Brazil" title="Immigration to Brazil">immigration</a>. About five million people from over 60 countries migrated to Brazil between 1808 and 1972, most of them of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Brazilian">Portuguese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Brazilian">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazilians_of_Spanish_descent" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilians of Spanish descent">Spanish</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="German Brazilian">German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian Brazilian">Ukrainian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Brazilian">Polish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish Brazilian">Jewish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russians_in_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Russians in Brazil">Russian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese Brazilian">Chinese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese Brazilian">Japanese</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Arab_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab Brazilian">Arab</a> origin.<sup id="cite_ref-491" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-491">[486]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492">[487]</a></sup> Brazil has the second largest Jewish community in Latin America making up 0.06% of its population.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_493-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-493">[488]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Brazil" title="Religion in Brazil">Religion in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Brazil" title="Catholic Church in Brazil">Catholic Church in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Brazil" title="Protestantism in Brazil">Protestantism in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px"> 
        <div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black"> 
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:WhiteSmoke"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 181.89932472811px; border-left-color:Chartreuse"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Chartreuse"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Chartreuse"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 117.83254560581px; border-left-color:Pink"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Pink"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Pink"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 91.568921586116px; border-left-color:Indigo"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Indigo"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Indigo"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:79.399039864784px 60.793029769461px 0 0; border-top-color:Gold"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Gold"></div> 
        </div> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <p><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Brazil" title="Religion in Brazil">Religion in Brazil</a> (2010 Census) </p> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Gold; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Brazil" title="Catholic Church in Brazil">Catholicism</a> (64.6%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Indigo; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Brazil" title="Protestantism in Brazil">Protestantism</a> (22.2%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Pink; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Spiritism" title="Spiritism">Spiritism</a> (2.0%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Chartreuse; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Other (3.2%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:WhiteSmoke; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;No religion (8.0%)
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism">Roman Catholicism</a> is the country's predominant faith. Brazil has the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">world's largest Catholic population</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-PEWCATHOLIC_494-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PEWCATHOLIC-494">[489]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-USDS_495-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USDS-495">[490]</a></sup> According to the 2010 Demographic Census (the PNAD survey does not inquire about religion), 64.63% of the population followed <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism in Brazil">Roman Catholicism</a>; 22.2% <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Brazil" title="Protestantism in Brazil">Protestantism</a>; 2.0% Kardecist spiritism; 3.2% other religions, undeclared or undetermined; while 8.0% have no religion.<sup id="cite_ref-census2010_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census2010-8">[5]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Religion in Brazil was formed from the meeting of the Catholic Church with the religious traditions of enslaved African peoples and indigenous peoples.<sup id="cite_ref-BoyleSheen2013_496-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoyleSheen2013-496">[491]</a></sup> This confluence of faiths during the Portuguese colonization of Brazil led to the development of a diverse array of syncretistic practices within the overarching umbrella of Brazilian Catholic Church, characterized by traditional Portuguese festivities,<sup id="cite_ref-georgetown1_497-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown1-497">[492]</a></sup> and in some instances, <a href="/wiki/Allan_Kardec" title="Allan Kardec">Allan Kardec</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Spiritism" title="Spiritism">Spiritism</a> (a religion which incorporates elements of <a href="/wiki/Spiritualism" title="Spiritualism">spiritualism</a> and Christianity). Religious pluralism increased during the 20th century,<sup id="cite_ref-Morris2006a_498-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris2006a-498">[493]</a></sup> and the Protestant community has grown to include over 22% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-JeynesRobinson2012_499-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JeynesRobinson2012-499">[494]</a></sup> The most common Protestant denominations are <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">Evangelical</a> <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">Pentecostal</a> ones. Other Protestant branches with a notable presence in the country include the <a href="/wiki/Baptists" title="Baptists">Baptists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutherans</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">Reformed tradition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-500" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-500">[495]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>However, in the last ten years Protestantism, particularly in forms of Pentecostalism and Evangelicalism, has spread in Brazil, while the proportion of Catholics has dropped significantly.<sup id="cite_ref-georgetown2_501-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown2-501">[496]</a></sup> After Protestantism, individuals professing no religion are also a significant group, exceeding 8% of the population as of the 2010 census. The cities of <a href="/wiki/Boa_Vista,_Roraima" title="Boa Vista, Roraima">Boa Vista</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia" title="Salvador, Bahia">Salvador</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Porto_Velho" title="Porto Velho">Porto Velho</a> have the greatest proportion of <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">Irreligious</a> residents in Brazil. <a href="/wiki/Teresina" title="Teresina">Teresina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Florian%C3%B3polis" title="Florianópolis">Florianópolis</a> were the most Roman Catholic in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-FGV_no_G1_502-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FGV_no_G1-502">[497]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Greater_Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Greater Rio de Janeiro">Greater Rio de Janeiro</a>, not including the <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">city proper</a>, is the most irreligious and least Roman Catholic Brazilian periphery, while <a href="/wiki/Greater_Porto_Alegre" title="Greater Porto Alegre">Greater Porto Alegre</a> and Greater <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a> are on the opposite sides of the lists, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-FGV_no_G1_502-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FGV_no_G1-502">[497]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg/220px-1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg/330px-1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg/440px-1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6432" data-file-height="4300"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <i><a href="/wiki/Christ_the_Redeemer_(statue)" title="Christ the Redeemer (statue)">Christ the Redeemer</a></i> statue in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> is one of the most famous religious statues worldwide<sup id="cite_ref-503" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-503">[498]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-504" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-504">[499]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In October 2009, the Brazilian Senate approved and enacted by the President of Brazil in February 2010, an agreement with the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Vatican</a>, in which the Legal Statute of the Catholic Church in Brazil is recognized. The agreement confirmed norms that were normally complied with regarding religious education in public elementary schools (which also ensures the teaching of other beliefs), marriage and spiritual assistance in prisons and hospitals. The project was criticized by parliamentarians who understood the end of the secular state with the approval of the agreement.<sup id="cite_ref-505" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-505">[500]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-506" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-506">[501]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_in_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="List of largest cities in Brazil">List of largest cities in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Brazil" title="Municipalities of Brazil">Municipalities of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <p>According to IBGE (Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics) urban areas already concentrate 84.35% of the population, while the Southeast region remains the most populated one, with over 80 million inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-507" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-507">[502]</a></sup> The largest urban agglomerations in Brazil are <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a> – all in the Southeastern Region – with 21.1, 12.3, and 5.1&nbsp;million inhabitants respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-concentrações_urbanas_508-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-concentrações_urbanas-508">[503]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509">[504]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-510" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-510">[505]</a></sup> The majority of state capitals are the largest cities in their states, except for <a href="/wiki/Vit%C3%B3ria,_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Vitória, Brazil">Vitória</a>, the capital of <a href="/wiki/Esp%C3%ADrito_Santo" title="Espírito Santo">Espírito Santo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Florian%C3%B3polis" title="Florianópolis">Florianópolis</a>, the capital of Santa Catarina.<sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511">[506]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Brazil" title="Languages of Brazil">Languages of Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese" title="Brazilian Portuguese">Brazilian Portuguese</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_languages_in_Brazil" title="List of endangered languages in Brazil">List of endangered languages in Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Interior_do_Museu_da_L%C3%ADngua_Portuguesa_em_S%C3%A3o_Paulo,_Brasil.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Interior_do_Museu_da_L%C3%ADngua_Portuguesa_em_S%C3%A3o_Paulo%2C_Brasil.jpg/220px-Interior_do_Museu_da_L%C3%ADngua_Portuguesa_em_S%C3%A3o_Paulo%2C_Brasil.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Interior_do_Museu_da_L%C3%ADngua_Portuguesa_em_S%C3%A3o_Paulo%2C_Brasil.jpg/330px-Interior_do_Museu_da_L%C3%ADngua_Portuguesa_em_S%C3%A3o_Paulo%2C_Brasil.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Interior_do_Museu_da_L%C3%ADngua_Portuguesa_em_S%C3%A3o_Paulo%2C_Brasil.jpg/440px-Interior_do_Museu_da_L%C3%ADngua_Portuguesa_em_S%C3%A3o_Paulo%2C_Brasil.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3504" data-file-height="2336"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Interior_do_Museu_da_L%C3%ADngua_Portuguesa_em_S%C3%A3o_Paulo,_Brasil.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Museum_of_the_Portuguese_Language" title="Museum of the Portuguese Language">Museum of the Portuguese Language</a> in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a> city, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="São Paulo (state)">São Paulo</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Parque_Ind%C3%ADgena_do_Xingu.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Parque_Ind%C3%ADgena_do_Xingu.jpg/220px-Parque_Ind%C3%ADgena_do_Xingu.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Parque_Ind%C3%ADgena_do_Xingu.jpg/330px-Parque_Ind%C3%ADgena_do_Xingu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Parque_Ind%C3%ADgena_do_Xingu.jpg/440px-Parque_Ind%C3%ADgena_do_Xingu.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2480" data-file-height="1568"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Parque_Ind%C3%ADgena_do_Xingu.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Oca_(structure)" title="Oca (structure)">Ocas</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Kuikuro_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Kuikuro people">Kuikuro people</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xingu_Indigenous_Park" title="Xingu Indigenous Park">Xingu Indigenous Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso" title="Mato Grosso">Mato Grosso</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The official language of Brazil is Portuguese<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_People_514-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_People-514">[509]</a></sup> (Article 13 of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Constitution of the Federal Republic of Brazil</a>), which almost all of the population speaks and is virtually the only language used in newspapers, radio, television, and for business and administrative purposes. Brazil is the only Portuguese-speaking nation in the Americas, making the language an important part of Brazilian national identity and giving it a national culture distinct from those of its Spanish-speaking neighbors.<sup id="cite_ref-language2_515-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-language2-515">[510]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese" title="Brazilian Portuguese">Brazilian Portuguese</a> has had its own development, mostly similar to 16th-century Central and Southern dialects of European Portuguese<sup id="cite_ref-516" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-516">[511]</a></sup> (despite a very substantial number of Portuguese colonial settlers, and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Brazilian">more recent immigrants</a>, coming from <a href="/wiki/Northern_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Portugal">Northern regions</a>, and in minor degree Portuguese <a href="/wiki/Macaronesia" title="Macaronesia">Macaronesia</a>), with a few influences from the <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_languages_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous languages of the Americas">Amerindian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Africa" title="Languages of Africa">African languages</a>, especially <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">West African</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bantu_languages" title="Bantu languages">Bantu</a> restricted to the vocabulary only.<sup id="cite_ref-Portuguese_517-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Portuguese-517">[512]</a></sup> As a result,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> the language is somewhat different, mostly in phonology, from the language of Portugal and other <a href="/wiki/Portuguese-speaking_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese-speaking countries">Portuguese-speaking countries</a> (the dialects of the other countries, partly because of the more recent end of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese colonialism</a> in these regions, have a closer connection to contemporary <a href="/wiki/European_Portuguese" title="European Portuguese">European Portuguese</a>). These differences are comparable to those between <a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">American</a> and <a href="/wiki/British_English" title="British English">British English</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Portuguese_517-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Portuguese-517">[512]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1990, the <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Portuguese_Language_Countries" title="Community of Portuguese Language Countries">Community of Portuguese Language Countries</a> (CPLP), which included representatives from all countries with Portuguese as the official language, reached an <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Language_Orthographic_Agreement_of_1990" title="Portuguese Language Orthographic Agreement of 1990">agreement on the reform of the Portuguese orthography</a> to unify the two standards then in use by Brazil on one side and the remaining lusophone countries on the other. This spelling reform went into effect in Brazil on 1 January 2009. In Portugal, the reform was signed into law by the President on 21 July 2008 allowing for a six-year adaptation period, during which both orthographies will co-exist. The remaining CPLP countries are free to establish their own transition timetables.<sup id="cite_ref-518" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-518">[513]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Recognition_of_sign_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Recognition of sign languages">sign language law</a> legally recognized in 2002,<sup id="cite_ref-Libras_2002_519-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Libras_2002-519">[514]</a></sup> (the law was <a href="/wiki/Regulation" title="Regulation">regulated</a> in 2005)<sup id="cite_ref-Libras_2005_520-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Libras_2005-520">[515]</a></sup> the use of the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Sign_Language" title="Brazilian Sign Language">Brazilian Sign Language</a>, more commonly known by its Portuguese <a href="/wiki/Acronym" title="Acronym">acronym</a> LIBRAS, in education and government services. The language must be taught as a part of the <a href="/wiki/School_of_education" title="School of education">education</a> and <a href="/wiki/Speech_and_language_pathology" class="mw-redirect" title="Speech and language pathology">speech and language pathology</a> curricula. LIBRAS teachers, instructors and translators are recognized professionals. Schools and health services must provide access ("<a href="/wiki/Inclusion_(education)" title="Inclusion (education)">inclusion</a>") to <a href="/wiki/Deaf_community" class="mw-redirect" title="Deaf community">deaf people</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Russo2011_521-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Russo2011-521">[516]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Festapomerana.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Festapomerana.jpg/220px-Festapomerana.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Festapomerana.jpg/330px-Festapomerana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Festapomerana.jpg/440px-Festapomerana.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Festapomerana.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Pomerode" title="Pomerode">Pomerode</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state)" title="Santa Catarina (state)">Santa Catarina</a>, is one of the municipalities with a cooficial language. In this region, <a href="/wiki/Hunsr%C3%BCckisch_dialect" title="Hunsrückisch dialect">Hunsrückisch</a> and <a href="/wiki/East_Pomeranian_dialect" title="East Pomeranian dialect">East Pomeranian</a>, German dialects, are two of the minor languages (see <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_German" title="Brazilian German">Brazilian German</a>).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Minority languages are spoken throughout the nation. One hundred and eighty <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_languages_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous languages of the Americas">Amerindian languages</a> are spoken in remote areas and a significant number of other languages are spoken by immigrants and their descendants.<sup id="cite_ref-Portuguese_517-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Portuguese-517">[512]</a></sup> In the municipality of <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Gabriel_da_Cachoeira" title="São Gabriel da Cachoeira">São Gabriel da Cachoeira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nheengatu_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Nheengatu language">Nheengatu</a> (a currently endangered South American <a href="/wiki/Creole_language" title="Creole language">creole language</a> – or an 'anti-creole', according to some linguists – with mostly Indigenous Brazilian languages lexicon and Portuguese-based grammar that, together with its southern relative <a href="/wiki/L%C3%ADngua_geral_paulista" class="mw-redirect" title="Língua geral paulista">língua geral paulista</a>, once was a major <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a> in Brazil,<sup id="cite_ref-522" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-522">[517]</a></sup> being replaced by Portuguese only after governmental prohibition led by <a href="/wiki/Suppression_of_the_Society_of_Jesus#Portugal" title="Suppression of the Society of Jesus">major political changes</a>)<sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint Template-Opinion" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:TERSE" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:TERSE"><span title="Statements that may be excessive (July 2015)">excessive detail?</span></a></i>]</sup>, <a href="/wiki/Baniwa_of_I%C3%A7ana" class="mw-redirect" title="Baniwa of Içana">Baniwa</a> and Tucano languages had been granted co-official status with Portuguese.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt-language_523-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-language-523">[518]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are significant communities of German (mostly the <a href="/wiki/Riograndenser_Hunsr%C3%BCckisch" class="mw-redirect" title="Riograndenser Hunsrückisch">Brazilian Hunsrückisch</a>, a High German language dialect) and Italian (mostly the <a href="/wiki/Talian_dialect" title="Talian dialect">Talian</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Venetian_language" title="Venetian language">Venetian</a> dialect) origins in the Southern and Southeastern regions, whose ancestors' native languages were carried along to Brazil, and which, still alive there, are influenced by the Portuguese language.<sup id="cite_ref-524" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-524">[519]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-525" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-525">[520]</a></sup> Talian is officially a historic patrimony of <a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande_do_Sul" title="Rio Grande do Sul">Rio Grande do Sul</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-526" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-526">[521]</a></sup> and two German dialects possess co-official status in a few municipalities.<sup id="cite_ref-Stevenson1997_527-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stevenson1997-527">[522]</a></sup> Italian is also recognized as <i>ethnic language</i> in the <a href="/wiki/Microregions_of_Brazil" title="Microregions of Brazil">Santa Teresa</a> microregion and <a href="/wiki/Vila_Velha" title="Vila Velha">Vila Velha</a> (Espirito Santo state), and is taught as mandatory second language at school.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_528-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-528">[523]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Learning at least one second language (generally English or Spanish) is mandatory for all the 12 grades of the mandatory <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Brazil" title="Education in Brazil">education system</a> (<a href="/wiki/Primary_education" title="Primary education">primary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education" title="Secondary education">secondary education</a>, there called <i>ensino fundamental</i> and <i>ensino médio</i> respectively). Brazil is the first country in South America to offer <a href="/wiki/Esperanto" title="Esperanto">Esperanto</a> to secondary students.<sup id="cite_ref-529" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-529">[524]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Brazil" title="Culture of Brazil">Culture of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Puro_ouro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Puro_ouro.jpg/220px-Puro_ouro.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="142" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Puro_ouro.jpg/330px-Puro_ouro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Puro_ouro.jpg/440px-Puro_ouro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1292"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Puro_ouro.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Interior of the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Francisco_Church_and_Convent" class="mw-redirect" title="São Francisco Church and Convent">São Francisco Church and Convent</a> in <a href="/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia" title="Salvador, Bahia">Salvador, Bahia</a>, one of the richest expressions of <a href="/wiki/Baroque_in_Brazil" title="Baroque in Brazil">Brazilian baroque</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The core culture of Brazil is derived from <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Portugal" title="Culture of Portugal">Portuguese culture</a>, because of its strong colonial ties with the Portuguese Empire.<sup id="cite_ref-Meade2009_530-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meade2009-530">[525]</a></sup> Among other influences, the Portuguese introduced the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholicism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manueline" title="Manueline">colonial architectural styles</a>. The culture was, however, also strongly influenced by <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnic groups of Africa">African</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Brazil" title="Indigenous peoples in Brazil">indigenous</a> and non-Portuguese European cultures and traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-Levinson1998_531-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levinson1998-531">[526]</a></sup> Some aspects of Brazilian culture were influenced by the contributions of <a href="/wiki/Italian_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Brazilian">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="German Brazilian">German</a> and other European as well as <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese Brazilian">Japanese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish Brazilian">Jewish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arab_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab Brazilian">Arab</a> immigrants who arrived in large numbers in the South and Southeast of Brazil during the 19th and 20th centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-Lesser2013a_532-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lesser2013a-532">[527]</a></sup> The Amerindians influenced Brazil's language and <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_cuisine" title="Brazilian cuisine">cuisine</a>; and the Africans influenced language, cuisine, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Brazil" title="Music of Brazil">music</a>, dance and religion.<sup id="cite_ref-533" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-533">[528]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_art" title="Brazilian art">Brazilian art</a> has developed since the 16th century into different styles that range from <a href="/wiki/Baroque_in_Brazil" title="Baroque in Brazil">Baroque</a> (the dominant style in Brazil until the early 19th century)<sup id="cite_ref-534" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-534">[529]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-itaucultural.org.br_535-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-itaucultural.org.br-535">[530]</a></sup> to <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_academic_art" title="Brazilian academic art">Romanticism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Modern_art" title="Modern art">Modernism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Expressionism" title="Expressionism">Expressionism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cubism" title="Cubism">Cubism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surrealism" title="Surrealism">Surrealism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abstract_art" title="Abstract art">Abstractionism</a>. <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Brazil" title="Cinema of Brazil">Brazilian cinema</a> dates back to the birth of the medium in the late 19th century and has gained a new level of international acclaim since the 1960s.<sup id="cite_ref-Marsh2012_536-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marsh2012-536">[531]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Brazil" title="Architecture of Brazil">Architecture of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Museudainconfidencia2006.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Museudainconfidencia2006.jpg/220px-Museudainconfidencia2006.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Museudainconfidencia2006.jpg/330px-Museudainconfidencia2006.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Museudainconfidencia2006.jpg/440px-Museudainconfidencia2006.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2701" data-file-height="1772"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Museudainconfidencia2006.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_the_Inconfid%C3%AAncia" class="mw-redirect" title="Museum of the Inconfidência">Museum of the Inconfidência</a> in <a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a>, an example of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_colonial_architecture" title="Portuguese colonial architecture">Portuguese colonial architecture</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Catedral_Metropolitana_de_Bras%C3%ADlia_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Catedral_Metropolitana_de_Bras%C3%ADlia_2.jpg/220px-Catedral_Metropolitana_de_Bras%C3%ADlia_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Catedral_Metropolitana_de_Bras%C3%ADlia_2.jpg/330px-Catedral_Metropolitana_de_Bras%C3%ADlia_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Catedral_Metropolitana_de_Bras%C3%ADlia_2.jpg/440px-Catedral_Metropolitana_de_Bras%C3%ADlia_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1250" data-file-height="870"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Catedral_Metropolitana_de_Bras%C3%ADlia_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Cathedral of Brasília">Cathedral of Brasília</a>, an example of <a href="/wiki/Modern_architecture" title="Modern architecture">Modern architecture</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The architecture of Brazil is influenced by Europe, especially Portugal. It has a history that goes back 500 years to the time when <a href="/wiki/Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral" title="Pedro Álvares Cabral">Pedro Cabral</a> discovered Brazil in 1500. <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_colonial_architecture" title="Portuguese colonial architecture">Portuguese colonial architecture</a> was the first wave of architecture to go to Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-537" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-537">[532]</a></sup> It is the basis for all Brazilian architecture of later centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-538" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-538">[533]</a></sup> In the 19th century during the time of the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Brazil" title="Empire of Brazil">Empire of Brazil</a>, Brazil followed European trends and adopted <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">Neoclassical</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture" title="Gothic Revival architecture">Gothic Revival architecture</a>. Then in the 20th century especially in Brasília, Brazil experimented with <a href="/wiki/Modernist_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Modernist architecture">Modernist architecture</a>. </p>
      <p>The colonial architecture of Brazil dates to the early 16th century when Brazil was first explored, conquered and settled by the Portuguese. The Portuguese built architecture familiar to them in Europe in their aim to colonize Brazil. They built Portuguese colonial architecture which included churches, civic architecture including houses and forts in Brazilian cities and the countryside. During 19th century Brazilian architecture saw the introduction of more European styles to Brazil such as Neoclassical and Gothic Revival architecture. This was usually mixed with Brazilian influences from their own heritage which produced a unique form of Brazilian architecture. In the 1950s the <a href="/wiki/Modernist_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Modernist architecture">modernist architecture</a> was introduced when Brasília was built as new federal capital in the interior of Brazil to help develop the interior. The architect <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Niemeyer" title="Oscar Niemeyer">Oscar Niemeyer</a> idealized and built government buildings, churches and civic buildings in the modernist style.<sup id="cite_ref-Guimaraens_539-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guimaraens-539">[534]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Claro_540-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Claro-540">[535]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Brazil" title="Music of Brazil">Music of Brazil</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:309px;max-width:309px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:122px;max-width:122px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Heitor_Vila-Lobos_(c._1922)part.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Heitor_Vila-Lobos_%28c._1922%29part.jpg/120px-Heitor_Vila-Lobos_%28c._1922%29part.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="175" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Heitor_Vila-Lobos_%28c._1922%29part.jpg/180px-Heitor_Vila-Lobos_%28c._1922%29part.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Heitor_Vila-Lobos_%28c._1922%29part.jpg/240px-Heitor_Vila-Lobos_%28c._1922%29part.jpg 2x" data-file-width="691" data-file-height="1010"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Heitor_Villa-Lobos" title="Heitor Villa-Lobos">Heitor Villa-Lobos</a>, the most widely known South American composer.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWright19924_541-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWright19924-541">[536]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:183px;max-width:183px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Tom_Jobim_e_Chico_Buarque_no_Festival_Internacional_da_Can%C3%A7%C3%A3o_(FIC).tif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Tom_Jobim_e_Chico_Buarque_no_Festival_Internacional_da_Can%C3%A7%C3%A3o_%28FIC%29.tif/lossy-page1-181px-Tom_Jobim_e_Chico_Buarque_no_Festival_Internacional_da_Can%C3%A7%C3%A3o_%28FIC%29.tif.jpg" decoding="async" width="181" height="175" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Tom_Jobim_e_Chico_Buarque_no_Festival_Internacional_da_Can%C3%A7%C3%A3o_%28FIC%29.tif/lossy-page1-272px-Tom_Jobim_e_Chico_Buarque_no_Festival_Internacional_da_Can%C3%A7%C3%A3o_%28FIC%29.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Tom_Jobim_e_Chico_Buarque_no_Festival_Internacional_da_Can%C3%A7%C3%A3o_%28FIC%29.tif/lossy-page1-362px-Tom_Jobim_e_Chico_Buarque_no_Festival_Internacional_da_Can%C3%A7%C3%A3o_%28FIC%29.tif.jpg 2x" data-file-width="9075" data-file-height="8752"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Tom_Jobim" class="mw-redirect" title="Tom Jobim">Tom Jobim</a>, one of the creators of <a href="/wiki/Bossa_nova" title="Bossa nova">bossa nova</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chico_Buarque" title="Chico Buarque">Chico Buarque</a>, one of the leading names of <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BAsica_popular_brasileira" title="Música popular brasileira">MPB</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The music of Brazil was formed mainly from the fusion of European and African elements.<sup id="cite_ref-FonsecaWeiner1991_542-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FonsecaWeiner1991-542">[537]</a></sup> Until the nineteenth century, Portugal was the gateway to most of the influences that built Brazilian music, although many of these elements were not of Portuguese origin, but generally European. The first was José Maurício Nunes Garcia, author of sacred pieces with influence of Viennese classicism.<sup id="cite_ref-Grazia2013_543-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Grazia2013-543">[538]</a></sup> The major contribution of the African element was the rhythmic diversity and some dances and instruments that had a bigger role in the development of popular music and folk, flourishing especially in the twentieth century.<sup id="cite_ref-FonsecaWeiner1991_542-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FonsecaWeiner1991-542">[537]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Popular music since the late eighteenth century began to show signs of forming a characteristically Brazilian sound, with <a href="/wiki/Samba_(music)" class="mw-redirect" title="Samba (music)">samba</a> considered the most typical and on the UNESCO cultural heritage list.<sup id="cite_ref-544" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-544">[539]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Maracatu" title="Maracatu">Maracatu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afox%C3%AA" title="Afoxê">Afoxê</a> are two <a href="/wiki/Afro-Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Afro-Brazilian">Afro-Brazilian</a> music traditions that have been popularized by their appearance in the annual <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Carnival" title="Brazilian Carnival">Brazilian Carnivals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Crook2009_545-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Crook2009-545">[540]</a></sup> The sport of <a href="/wiki/Capoeira" title="Capoeira">capoeira</a> is usually played with its own music referred to as <a href="/wiki/Capoeira_music" title="Capoeira music">capoeira music</a>, which is usually considered to be a call-and-response type of folk music.<sup id="cite_ref-Fryer2000_546-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fryer2000-546">[541]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Forr%C3%B3" title="Forró">Forró</a> is a type of folk music prominent during the <a href="/wiki/Festa_Junina" title="Festa Junina">Festa Junina</a> in <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Northeast Region, Brazil">northeastern Brazil</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-547" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-547">[542]</a></sup> Jack A. Draper III, a professor of Portuguese at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Missouri" title="University of Missouri">University of Missouri</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-548" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-548">[543]</a></sup> argues that Forró was used as a way to subdue feelings of nostalgia for a rural lifestyle.<sup id="cite_ref-549" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-549">[544]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Choro" title="Choro">Choro</a> is a very popular music instrumental style. Its origins are in 19th-century Rio de Janeiro. In spite of the name, the style often has a fast and happy rhythm, characterized by virtuosity, improvisation, subtle <a href="/wiki/Modulation_(music)" title="Modulation (music)">modulations</a> and full of <a href="/wiki/Syncopation" title="Syncopation">syncopation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Counterpoint" title="Counterpoint">counterpoint</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MacGowanPessanha1998_550-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacGowanPessanha1998-550">[545]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bossa_nova" title="Bossa nova">Bossa nova</a> is also a well-known style of Brazilian music developed and popularized in the 1950s and 1960s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacGowanPessanha1998[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid7MFD-EoTR7MCpgPA6_6]_551-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacGowanPessanha1998[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid7MFD-EoTR7MCpgPA6_6]-551">[546]</a></sup> The phrase "bossa nova" means literally "new trend".<sup id="cite_ref-Kassing2007_552-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kassing2007-552">[547]</a></sup> A lyrical fusion of samba and <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a>, bossa nova acquired a large following starting in the 1960s.<sup id="cite_ref-Campbell2011b_553-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Campbell2011b-553">[548]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_literature" title="Brazilian literature">Brazilian literature</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:293px;max-width:293px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:137px;max-width:137px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Machado_de_Assis_aos_57_anos.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Machado_de_Assis_aos_57_anos.jpg/135px-Machado_de_Assis_aos_57_anos.jpg" decoding="async" width="135" height="198" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Machado_de_Assis_aos_57_anos.jpg/203px-Machado_de_Assis_aos_57_anos.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Machado_de_Assis_aos_57_anos.jpg/270px-Machado_de_Assis_aos_57_anos.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1263" data-file-height="1852"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Machado_de_Assis" title="Machado de Assis">Machado de Assis</a>, poet and novelist, founder of the <a href="/wiki/Academia_Brasileira_de_Letras" title="Academia Brasileira de Letras">Brazilian Academy of Letters</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Carlos_Drummond_de_Andrade,_1970.tif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Carlos_Drummond_de_Andrade%2C_1970.tif/lossy-page1-150px-Carlos_Drummond_de_Andrade%2C_1970.tif.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="195" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Carlos_Drummond_de_Andrade%2C_1970.tif/lossy-page1-225px-Carlos_Drummond_de_Andrade%2C_1970.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Carlos_Drummond_de_Andrade%2C_1970.tif/lossy-page1-300px-Carlos_Drummond_de_Andrade%2C_1970.tif.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2535" data-file-height="3299"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Drummond_de_Andrade" title="Carlos Drummond de Andrade">Carlos Drummond de Andrade</a>, considered by some as the greatest Brazilian poet.<sup id="cite_ref-554" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-554">[549]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_literature" title="Brazilian literature">Brazilian literature</a> dates back to the 16th century, to the writings of the first Portuguese explorers in Brazil, such as <a href="/wiki/P%C3%AAro_Vaz_de_Caminha" title="Pêro Vaz de Caminha">Pêro Vaz de Caminha</a>, filled with descriptions of <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">fauna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flora" title="Flora">flora</a> and commentary about the indigenous population that fascinated European readers.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA360_360]_555-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA360_360]-555">[550]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Brazil produced significant works in <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a> – novelists like <a href="/wiki/Joaquim_Manuel_de_Macedo" title="Joaquim Manuel de Macedo">Joaquim Manuel de Macedo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_de_Alencar" title="José de Alencar">José de Alencar</a> wrote novels about love and pain. Alencar, in his long career, also treated indigenous people as heroes in the <a href="/wiki/Indianism_(arts)" title="Indianism (arts)">Indigenist</a> novels <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guarani" title="The Guarani">O Guarani</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Iracema" title="Iracema">Iracema</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Ubirajara" class="mw-redirect" title="Ubirajara">Ubirajara</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-556" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-556">[551]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Machado_de_Assis" title="Machado de Assis">Machado de Assis</a>, one of his contemporaries, wrote in virtually all genres and continues to gain international prestige from critics worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-557" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-557">[552]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-558" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-558">[553]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-559" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-559">[554]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_literature#Modernism" title="Brazilian literature">Brazilian Modernism</a>, evidenced by the <a href="/wiki/Week_of_Modern_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Week of Modern Art">Week of Modern Art</a> in 1922, was concerned with a nationalist avant-garde literature,<sup id="cite_ref-560" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-560">[555]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_literature#Post-Modernism" title="Brazilian literature">Post-Modernism</a> brought a generation of distinct poets like <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Cabral_de_Melo_Neto" title="João Cabral de Melo Neto">João Cabral de Melo Neto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Drummond_de_Andrade" title="Carlos Drummond de Andrade">Carlos Drummond de Andrade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vinicius_de_Moraes" title="Vinicius de Moraes">Vinicius de Moraes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cora_Coralina" title="Cora Coralina">Cora Coralina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Graciliano_Ramos" title="Graciliano Ramos">Graciliano Ramos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cec%C3%ADlia_Meireles" title="Cecília Meireles">Cecília Meireles</a>, and internationally known writers dealing with universal and regional subjects like <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Amado" title="Jorge Amado">Jorge Amado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Guimar%C3%A3es_Rosa" title="João Guimarães Rosa">João Guimarães Rosa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clarice_Lispector" title="Clarice Lispector">Clarice Lispector</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Bandeira" title="Manuel Bandeira">Manuel Bandeira</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-561" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-561">[556]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-562" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-562">[557]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-563" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-563">[558]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_cuisine" title="Brazilian cuisine">Brazilian cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Brazilian_dishes" title="List of Brazilian dishes">List of Brazilian dishes</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pao_de_queijo_com_cafe.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pao_de_queijo_com_cafe.jpg/220px-Pao_de_queijo_com_cafe.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pao_de_queijo_com_cafe.jpg/330px-Pao_de_queijo_com_cafe.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pao_de_queijo_com_cafe.jpg/440px-Pao_de_queijo_com_cafe.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pao_de_queijo_com_cafe.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/P%C3%A3o_de_queijo" title="Pão de queijo">Pão de queijo</a> with <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_coffee" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian coffee">coffee</a> and a small <a href="/wiki/Cacha%C3%A7a" title="Cachaça">cachaça</a> bottle, examples of the cuisine from the interior of Brazil
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
